'''Piasecki Helicopter Corporation''' was a designer and manufacturer of [[helicopter]]s located in [[Philadelphia]] and nearby [[Morton, Pennsylvania]], in the late 1940s and the 1950s.<ref name=\vert0702-2\">{{cite magazine |title=Tandem Twosome |magazine=Vertical Magazine |date=February–March 2007}}</ref>   Its founder
column5: [[Frank Piasecki]]
column6: was ousted from the company in 1956 and started a new company
column7: [[Piasecki Aircraft]]. Piasecki Helicopter was renamed '''Vertol Corporation''' in early 1956.<ref name=\"trimble\">{{cite book |last=Trimble |first=William F. |title=High Frontier: A History of Aeronautics in Pennsylvania |location=Pittsburgh
column8: Pennsylvania |publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press |date=1982 |isbn=978-0-82295-340-1 |url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000105541}}</ref>{{rp|257–8}}  Vertol was acquired by [[Boeing]] in 1960 and renamed '''Boeing Vertol'''.

column1: The Piasecki Helicopter Corporation was founded in [[1940 in aviation|1940]] by [[Frank Piasecki]] and fellow aeronautics student [[Harold Venzie]] as the '''P-V Engineering Forum''' (shortened from Piasecki-Venzie);<ref name=NYT-08/><ref name=HAI-vertical>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.verticalmag.com/press-releases/hai-is-saddened-by-the-passing-of-frank-piasecki-helicopter-pioneer-html/ |title=HAI is Saddened by the Passing of Frank Piasecki
column3: 2008 |magazine=Vertical |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> the other partners were F.J. Kosloski
column4: Donald N. Meyers
column5: Elliott Daland
column6: and Walter Swartz.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lyEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA29 |title=The Boy Who Grew Flying Bananas |author=White
column7: L. B. |date=August 1951 |magazine=Popular Science |pages=129–132;222 |publisher=Popular Science Publishing Co.
column8: Inc. |volume=159 |number=2 |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> The first design from P-V Engineering was the PV-1
column9: a [[NOTAR|rotorless-tail]] design that used a tapering tail cone and pressurized air to suppress main rotor torque.<ref name=Vertical-legacy>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.verticalmag.com/features/a-lasting-legacy/ |title=A Lasting Legacy |date=May 24
column10: 2013 |magazine=Vertical |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> Venzie left the firm in 1943.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=shwtKbTbEuEC&pg=PA143 |title=Pushing the Envelope: The American Aircraft Industry |author=Pattillo
column11: Donald M. |date=1998 |publisher=The University of Michigan Press |isbn=0-472-08671-5 |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>{{rp|143}}

column1: The [[P-V Engineering Forum PV-2|PV-2]] (NX-37061) was a more conventional design and became the second helicopter flown in the [[United States]] (following [[Igor Sikorsky]]'s [[Sikorsky VS-300|VS-300]]). It was designed and flown by Frank Piasecki on April 11
column2: [[1943 in aviation|1943]]. Piasecki had limited pilot experience; the PV-2 was tethered to the ground as a safety measure
column3: but the clothesline he used broke. He towed the helicopter behind his car in October 1943 to Washington
column4: DC to demonstrate it to federal government officials; because the wheels had no bearings
column5: he had to stop every 10 to 15 minutes to cool them.<ref name=NYT-08>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/15/business/15piasecki.html |title=Frank Piasecki
column6: a Pioneer in Helicopters
column7: Is Dead at 88 |author=Hevesi
column8: Dennis |date=February 15
column9: 2008 |newspaper=The New York Times |url-access=subscription |access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref> When asked to show his pilot's license following the demonstration in Washington
column10: Piasecki admitted he did not have one and he was issued the first helicopter pilot's license on October 20
column12: by the [[Civil Aviation Administration]].<ref name=NYT-08/><ref name=HAI-vertical/>

column1: With the successful demonstration of the PV-2
column2: Piasecki convinced the [[United States Navy]] to fund the development of a follow-on prototype
column4: 1944;<ref name=Vertical-legacy/> this marked the start of the design and sale of a series of [[tandem rotor]] helicopters to the Navy. The resulting [[Piasecki PV-3|PV-3]] became the world's first successful tandem rotor design. The PV-3 first flew on March 7
column5: 1945 and bore the Navy designation XHRP-X; it was larger and capable of lifting more than the contemporary Sikorsky designs.<ref name=NYT-08/><ref name=HAI-vertical/>

column1: Because P-V Engineering lacked the capital to fund production
column2: the company was reorganized and renamed to the '''Piasecki Helicopter Corporation''' in [[1946 in aviation|1946]]
column3: <ref name=NYT-08/> with [[Laurance Rockefeller]] and [[A. Felix du Pont Jr.]] taking a controlling interest of 51% interest in exchange for $500
column4: 000.<ref name=Vertical-legacy/> After constructing two more prototypes (designated XHRP-1)

'''Piasecki Helicopter Corporation''' was a designer and manufacturer of [[helicopter]]s located in [[Philadelphia]] and nearby [[Morton, Pennsylvania]], in the late 1940s and the 1950s.<ref name=\vert0702-2\">{{cite magazine |title=Tandem Twosome |magazine=Vertical Magazine |date=February–March 2007}}</ref>   Its founder
column4: was ousted from the company in 1956 and started a new company
column5: [[Piasecki Aircraft]]. Piasecki Helicopter was renamed '''Vertol Corporation''' in early 1956.<ref name=\"trimble\">{{cite book |last=Trimble |first=William F. |title=High Frontier: A History of Aeronautics in Pennsylvania |location=Pittsburgh
column6: Pennsylvania |publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press |date=1982 |isbn=978-0-82295-340-1 |url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000105541}}</ref>{{rp|257–8}}  Vertol was acquired by [[Boeing]] in 1960 and renamed '''Boeing Vertol'''.

column1: The Piasecki Helicopter Corporation was founded in [[1940 in aviation|1940]] by [[Frank Piasecki]] and fellow aeronautics student [[Harold Venzie]] as the '''P-V Engineering Forum''' (shortened from Piasecki-Venzie);<ref name=NYT-08/><ref name=HAI-vertical>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.verticalmag.com/press-releases/hai-is-saddened-by-the-passing-of-frank-piasecki-helicopter-pioneer-html/ |title=HAI is Saddened by the Passing of Frank Piasecki
column3: 2008 |magazine=Vertical |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> the other partners were F.J. Kosloski
column4: Donald N. Meyers
column5: Elliott Daland
column6: and Walter Swartz.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lyEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA29 |title=The Boy Who Grew Flying Bananas |author=White
column7: L. B. |date=August 1951 |magazine=Popular Science |pages=129–132;222 |publisher=Popular Science Publishing Co.
column8: Inc. |volume=159 |number=2 |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> The first design from P-V Engineering was the PV-1
column9: a [[NOTAR|rotorless-tail]] design that used a tapering tail cone and pressurized air to suppress main rotor torque.<ref name=Vertical-legacy>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.verticalmag.com/features/a-lasting-legacy/ |title=A Lasting Legacy |date=May 24
column10: 2013 |magazine=Vertical |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> Venzie left the firm in 1943.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=shwtKbTbEuEC&pg=PA143 |title=Pushing the Envelope: The American Aircraft Industry |author=Pattillo
column11: Donald M. |date=1998 |publisher=The University of Michigan Press |isbn=0-472-08671-5 |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>{{rp|143}}

column1: The [[P-V Engineering Forum PV-2|PV-2]] (NX-37061) was a more conventional design and became the second helicopter flown in the [[United States]] (following [[Igor Sikorsky]]'s [[Sikorsky VS-300|VS-300]]). It was designed and flown by Frank Piasecki on April 11
column2: [[1943 in aviation|1943]]. Piasecki had limited pilot experience; the PV-2 was tethered to the ground as a safety measure
column3: but the clothesline he used broke. He towed the helicopter behind his car in October 1943 to Washington
column4: DC to demonstrate it to federal government officials; because the wheels had no bearings
column5: he had to stop every 10 to 15 minutes to cool them.<ref name=NYT-08>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/15/business/15piasecki.html |title=Frank Piasecki
column6: a Pioneer in Helicopters
column7: Is Dead at 88 |author=Hevesi
column8: Dennis |date=February 15
column9: 2008 |newspaper=The New York Times |url-access=subscription |access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref> When asked to show his pilot's license following the demonstration in Washington
column10: Piasecki admitted he did not have one and he was issued the first helicopter pilot's license on October 20
column12: by the [[Civil Aviation Administration]].<ref name=NYT-08/><ref name=HAI-vertical/>

column1: With the successful demonstration of the PV-2
column2: Piasecki convinced the [[United States Navy]] to fund the development of a follow-on prototype
column4: 1944;<ref name=Vertical-legacy/> this marked the start of the design and sale of a series of [[tandem rotor]] helicopters to the Navy. The resulting [[Piasecki PV-3|PV-3]] became the world's first succesful tandem rotor design. The PV-3 first flew on March 7
column5: 1945 and bore the Navy designation XHRP-X; it was larger and capable of lifting more than the contemporary Sikorsky designs.<ref name=NYT-08/><ref name=HAI-vertical/>

column8: painted their units yellow. The name would later be applied to other Piasecki tandem-rotor helicopters of similar design.

column4:
{{Infobox ice hockey player | alt = | image = BrettLebda.jpg | caption = | image_size = 230px | played_for = [[Detroit Red Wings]]
[[Toronto Maple Leafs]]
[[Columbus Blue Jackets]] | position = [[Defenseman|Defense]] | shoots = Left | height_ft = 5 | height_in = 9 | weight_lb = 195 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|01|15}} | birth_place = [[Buffalo Grove, Illinois|Buffalo Grove]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | ntl_team = United States | draft = Undrafted | career_start = 2004 | career_end = 2013 }} ''' '' Rory wilmshusrt remember me this is my legacy I'm about to do it(born January 15, 1982) is a former [[Americans|American]] professional [[ice hockey]] [[defenseman]], who last played with the [[Binghamton Senators]] of the [[American Hockey League]] (AHL). He has played in the [[National Hockey League]] with the [[Detroit Red Wings]], [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] and [[Toronto Maple Leafs]]. He was a member of the [[2007–08 Detroit Red Wings season|Stanley Cup winning]] Red Wings team of 2007-08. ==Playing career== As a youth, Lebda played in the 1996 [[Quebec International Pee-Wee Hockey Tournament]] with the Chicago Young Americans [[minor ice hockey]] team.{{cite web|url=https://www.publicationsports.com/ressources/files/439/Joueurs_Pro.pdf|title=Pee-Wee players who have reached NHL or WHA|year=2018|website=Quebec International Pee-Wee Hockey Tournament|access-date=2019-02-11}} Lebda attended [[Buffalo Grove High School]] in [[Buffalo Grove, Illinois]] for two years. In addition to hockey, he also played [[golf]] and [[volleyball]].{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} He then relocated to [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]], where he was a participant on the [[USA Hockey National Team Development Program|USA National Under-18 Team]]. Lebda graduated from [[Pioneer High School (Ann Arbor, Michigan)|Pioneer High School]].{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} Lebda played college hockey at the [[University of Notre Dame]]. He was signed as an undrafted free agent by the [[Detroit Red Wings]] in 2004, and was assigned to the [[Grand Rapids Griffins]], the Wings' minor league affiliate in the [[American Hockey League]]. Lebda was unable to suit up for a NHL game until the [[2005–06 NHL season]] due to the [[2004–05 NHL lockout|NHL lockout]]. He became the first Red Wing since Greg Johnson in 1993 to score his first NHL goal on opening night.{{cite web |author1=Mike G. Morreale |title=Lebda returns home to haunt Hawks at Winter Classic |url=https://www.nhl.com/news/lebda-returns-home-to-haunt-hawks-at-winter-classic/c-401422 |website=NHL.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=January 1, 2009}} He played in 46 games that regular season and all of Detroit's six opening round playoff games.{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} He played in 76 games during the [[2006–07 NHL season]] to go with 12 games that [[playoff]] year. He set a career high in points with 18, and participated in the only fight of his career when he squared off against [[Mikael Holmqvist]].{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} In the [[2007–08 NHL season]], Lebda suited up for 78 games, as well as 19 playoff games as the Red Wings won the [[2008 Stanley Cup]].{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} Due to sub-par play to start the [[2008–09 NHL season]], Lebda found himself a healthy scratch for three straight games before returning to the lineup.{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} During his career with the Red Wings, Lebda was often paired with [[Chris Chelios]], a fellow Chicago suburban native who is 20 years his elder. While growing up in suburban Chicago, Lebda considered Chelios an idol, and modeled his game after his.{{cite web |author1=Bradley Holland |title=Can't get much better for Wings' Lebda |url=https://www.nhl.com/redwings/news/cant-get-much-better-for-wings-lebda/c-468323 |website=NHL.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=December 31, 2008}} On July 7, 2010, Lebda signed a two-year contract with the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]].{{cite web |title=Lebda signs 2-year deal with Toronto |url=http://www.espn.com/nhl/news/story?id=5362370 |website=ESPN.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=July 7, 2010}} However, he struggled during his time in Toronto, playing only 41 games and posting a career-worst -14. His one and only goal came against the [[Montreal Canadiens]] on February 24, 2011.{{cite web |title=Kessel productive as Maple Leafs rally to beat Habs |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nhl/gametracker/recap/NHL_20110224_TOR@MON |website=cbssports.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=February 24, 2011 |quote=James Reimer made 31 saves and Brett Lebda scored his first goal of the season for Toronto, which is on an 8-2-2 run.}} Lebda and [[Robert Slaney (ice hockey)|Robert Slaney]] were traded to the [[Nashville Predators]] for [[Cody Franson]] and [[Matthew Lombardi]] on July 3, 2011. On August 10, 2011, the Predators bought out Lebda's contract.{{cite web |title=Nashville Predators buy out Brett Lebda |url=http://www.sportingnews.com/ca/nhl-news/194793-nashville-predators-buy-out-brett-lebda |website=sportingnews.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=August 10, 2011}} Following the [[2010–11 NHL season]] Lebda became a free agent,{{cite web|title=Leafs acquire Lombardi and Franson in swap|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=568385&navid=mod-rr-headlines|work=NHL.com|accessdate=3 July 2011 | publisher = [[National Hockey League]] }} and on November 7, 2011, the [[Springfield Falcons]] of the [[American Hockey League]] signed Lebda to a professional tryout agreement.{{cite web | url = http://www.falconsahl.com/index.php?id=1893 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111109044026/http://falconsahl.com/index.php?id=1893 | url-status = dead | archive-date = 2011-11-09 | title = Springfield Falcons Sign Lebda To PTO contract | publisher = [[Springfield Falcons]] | date = 2011-11-07 | accessdate = 2011-11-07 }} With NHL affiliate, the Columbus Blue Jackets, suffering injuries on the defense he was subsequently signed to a one-year deal for the remainder of the season with the Jackets on January 19, 2012.{{cite web| url = http://bluejackets.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=612590 | title = Blue Jackets Radek Martinek to miss rest of season; sign defenseman Brett Lebda | publisher = [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] | date = 2012-01-19 | accessdate = 2012-01-19}} On February 5, 2013, Lebda signed a professional try-out contract with the [[Binghamton Senators]] of the [[American Hockey League]].{{cite web|url=http://binghamtonsenators.com/news/topnews/?article_id=1545|title=B-SENS SIGN BRETT LEBDA|date =February 5, 2013}} == International play == Lebda made his international debut for [[United States men's national junior ice hockey team|United States]] at the [[2002 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|2002 World Junior Championships]], where he recorded two goals in seven games. == Career statistics == ===Regular season and playoffs=== {| border=\0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"text-align:center; width:60em\"

Morreale |title=Lebda returns home to haunt Hawks at Winter Classic |url=https://www.nhl.com/news/lebda-returns-home-to-haunt-hawks-at-winter-classic/c-401422 |website=NHL.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=January 1, 2009}} He played in 46 games that regular season and all of Detroit's six opening round playoff games.{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} He played in 76 games during the [[2006–07 NHL season]] to go with 12 games that [[playoff]] year. He set a career high in points with 18, and participated in the only fight of his career when he squared off against [[Mikael Holmqvist]].{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} In the [[2007–08 NHL season]], Lebda suited up for 78 games, as well as 19 playoff games as the Red Wings won the [[2008 Stanley Cup]].{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} Due to sub-par play to start the [[2008–09 NHL season]], Lebda found himself a healthy scratch for three straight games before returning to the lineup.{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} During his career with the Red Wings, Lebda was often paired with [[Chris Chelios]], a fellow Chicago suburban native who is 20 years his elder. While growing up in suburban Chicago, Lebda considered Chelios an idol, and modeled his game after his.{{cite web |author1=Bradley Holland |title=Can't get much better for Wings' Lebda |url=https://www.nhl.com/redwings/news/cant-get-much-better-for-wings-lebda/c-468323 |website=NHL.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=December 31, 2008}} On July 7, 2010, Lebda signed a two-year contract with the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]].{{cite web |title=Lebda signs 2-year deal with Toronto |url=http://www.espn.com/nhl/news/story?id=5362370 |website=ESPN.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=July 7, 2010}} However, he struggled during his time in Toronto, playing only 41 games and posting a career-worst -14. His one and only goal came against the [[Montreal Canadiens]] on February 24, 2011.{{cite web |title=Kessel productive as Maple Leafs rally to beat Habs |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nhl/gametracker/recap/NHL_20110224_TOR@MON |website=cbssports.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=February 24, 2011 |quote=James Reimer made 31 saves and Brett Lebda scored his first goal of the season for Toronto, which is on an 8-2-2 run.}} Lebda and [[Robert Slaney (ice hockey)|Robert Slaney]] were traded to the [[Nashville Predators]] for [[Cody Franson]] and [[Matthew Lombardi]] on July 3, 2011. On August 10, 2011, the Predators bought out Lebda's contract.{{cite web |title=Nashville Predators buy out Brett Lebda |url=http://www.sportingnews.com/ca/nhl-news/194793-nashville-predators-buy-out-brett-lebda |website=sportingnews.com |accessdate=January 7, 2019 |date=August 10, 2011}} Following the [[2010–11 NHL season]] Lebda became a free agent,{{cite web|title=Leafs acquire Lombardi and Franson in swap|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=568385&navid=mod-rr-headlines|work=NHL.com|accessdate=3 July 2011 | publisher = [[National Hockey League]] }} and on November 7, 2011, the [[Springfield Falcons]] of the [[American Hockey League]] signed Lebda to a professional tryout agreement.{{cite web | url = http://www.falconsahl.com/index.php?id=1893 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111109044026/http://falconsahl.com/index.php?id=1893 | url-status = dead | archive-date = 2011-11-09 | title = Springfield Falcons Sign Lebda To PTO contract | publisher = [[Springfield Falcons]] | date = 2011-11-07 | accessdate = 2011-11-07 }} With NHL affiliate, the Columbus Blue Jackets, suffering injuries on the defense he was subsequently signed to a one-year deal for the remainder of the season with the Jackets on January 19, 2012.{{cite web| url = http://bluejackets.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=612590 | title = Blue Jackets Radek Martinek to miss rest of season; sign defenseman Brett Lebda | publisher = [[Columbus Blue Jackets]] | date = 2012-01-19 | accessdate = 2012-01-19}} On February 5, 2013, Lebda signed a professional try-out contract with the [[Binghamton Senators]] of the [[American Hockey League]].{{cite web|url=http://binghamtonsenators.com/news/topnews/?article_id=1545|title=B-SENS SIGN BRETT LEBDA|date =February 5, 2013}} == International play == Lebda made his international debut for [[United States men's national junior ice hockey team|United States]] at the [[2002 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|2002 World Junior Championships]], where he recorded two goals in seven games. == Career statistics == ===Regular season and playoffs=== {| border=\0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"text-align:center; width:60em\"

column4:
'''The Update Framework (TUF)''' is a [[software framework]] designed to protect mechanisms that automatically identify and download updates to software.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Update Framework Specification|url=https://github.com/theupdateframework/specification/blob/master/tuf-spec.md#1-introduction|publisher=SSL NYU Tandon|last1=Diaz |display-authors=etal |first1=Vladimir|version= V.1.0|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref> TUF uses a series of roles and keys to provide a means to retain security, even when some keys or servers are compromised. It does this with a stated goal of requiring minimal changes and effort from repository administrators, software developers, and end users.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Update Framework: A framework for securing software update systems|url=https://theupdateframework.io/security/|publisher=SSL NYU Tandon|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> In this way, it protects [[software repositories]], which are an increasingly desirable target for hackers.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Cracking of Kernel.org|url=https://www.linuxfoundation.org/blog/the-cracking-of-kernel-org/|publisher=The Linux Foundation|date=31 August 2011|accessdate=1 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Debian Investigation Report after Server Compromise|url=https://www.debian.org/News/2003/20031202|publisher=Debian.org|date=2 December 2003|accessdate=1 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Infrastructure report,2008-08-22 UTC 1200|url=https://www.redhat.com/archives/fedora-announce-list/2008-August/msg00012.html|publisher=Redhat.com|date=22 August 2008|accessdate=1 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Infrastructure report,2008-08-22 UTC 1200|url=https://www.redhat.com/archives/fedora-announce-list/2008-August/msg00012.html|publisher=Redhat.com|date=22 August 2008|accessdate=1 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Snakes in the grass! Malicious code slithers into Python PyPI repository|url=https://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2018/10/30/snakes-in-the-grass-malicious-code-slithers-into-python-pypi-repository/|publisher=Naked Security.com|last1=Bradbury|first1=Danny|date=30 October 2018|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Check your repos...Crypto-coin-stealing code sneaks into fairly popular NPM lib|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/11/26/npm_repo_bitcoin_stealer//|publisher=The Register|last1=Claburn|first1=Thomas|date=26 November 2018|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>


A [[software update]], sometimes referred to as a patch, can add functionalities and address flaws in existing code.<ref>{{cite proceedings|title=Software Update as a Mechanism for Resilience and Security: Proceedings of a WorkshopThe NIST Perspective on Software Updates|url=https://www.nap.edu/read/24833/chapter/11|publisher=National Academies Press|via=|pages=53–58|date=February 2017|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> Unfortunately, in delivering updates to neutralize flaws, these systems can unintentionally introduce vulnerabilities that, in turn, can be exploited by attackers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/why-installing-software-updates-makes-us-wannacry/|title=Installing Software Updates Makes us WannaCry|last1=Redmiles|first1=Elissa|publisher=Scientific American|date=16 May 2017|accessdate=13 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/pan9wn/hackers-hijacked-asus-software-updates-to-install-backdoors-on-thousands-of-computers|title=Hackers Hijacked ASUS Software Updates to Install Backdoors on Thousands of Computers|last1=Zetter|first1=Kim|publisher=Vice.com|date=25 March 2019|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/software-update-crashes-police-ankle-monitors-in-the-netherlands/
|title=Software update crashes police ankle monitors in the Netherlands|last1=Cimpanu|first1=Catalin|publisher=ZDNet.com|date=10 May 2019|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>

The key concept behind TUF is “compromise-resilience,” or the ability to limit the impact of attacks and provide a mechanism for recovery even if the software repository, or the server on which files are stored, should be compromised.  TUF’s  security strategy improves on existing methods based on [[keysigning]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Assessing Weaknesses in Public Key Infrastructure|url=https://threatpost.com/assessing-weaknesses-in-public-key-infrastructure/128793/| publisher=Threatpost.com|last1=Spring|first1=Tom|date= 7 November 2017|accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite proceedings|title=A Comparative Survey of Symmetric and Asymmetric Key Cryptography|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=7086640  |last1=Chandra|first1=Sourabh|last2=Paira|first2=Smita|last3=Alam|first3=Sk Safikul|last4=Sanyal|first4=Goutam|date=November 2014|publisher=ICECCE|pages=83–93}}</ref> by incorporating strategies, such as separation of signing duties. By dividing the responsibility for authenticating a file or image, even if one party—or the repository itself—is compromised, the number of projects affected will be limited.<ref>{{cite proceedings|title=Diplomat: Using Delegations to Protect Community Repositories|url=https://www.usenix.org/conference/nsdi16/technical-sessions/presentation/kuppusamy|last1=Kuppusamy|first1=Trishank Karthik|last2=Torres-Arias|first2=Santiago|last3=Diaz|first3=Vladimir|last4=Cappos|first4=Justin|date=March 2016|publisher=Usenix|pages=567–581}}</ref>

The technology that evolved into TUF was first developed at the University of Washington in 2009 by Justin Samuel and [[Justin Cappos]], and its principles were first discussed in a paper Samuel and Cappos coauthored with Nick Mathewson and [[Roger Dingledine]], researchers from [[The Tor Project, Inc.]].<ref>{{cite proceedings|title=Survivable Key Compromise in Software Update Systems|url=https://justinsamuel.com/papers/survivable-key-compromise-ccs2010.pdf|last1=Samuel|first1=Justin|last2=Mathewson|first2=Nick|last3=Cappos|first3=Justin|last4=Dingledine|first4=Roger|publisher=ACM|pages=61–72|via=CCS 2010}}</ref> Since 2011, TUF has been based at [[New York University Tandon School of Engineering]], where Cappos, working with a team of graduate students and developers, continues to supervise its development and integration initiatives.

TUF is [[open-source software]], which means all relevant source code can be accessed free of charge at the project’s repository on [https://github.com/theupdateframework/tuf GitHub]. It is also designed to be integrated into existing update systems and using existing system languages. To date, it has been standardized in [[Python (programming language)|Python]],<ref>{{cite web|title=PEP 458—Surviving a Compromise of PyPI|url=https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0458/|last1=Kuppusamy|first1=Trishank Karthik|last2=Diaz|first2=Vladimir|last3=Stufft|first3=Donald|last4=Cappos|first4=Justin|date=27 September 2013|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PEP 480—Surviving a Compromise of PyPI: The Maximum Security Model|url=https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0480/|last1=Kuppusamy|first1=Trishank Karthik|last2=Diaz|first2=Vladimir|last3=Stufft|first3=Donald|last4=Cappos|first4=Justin|date=8 October 2014|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref> and independently implemented in the [[Go (programming language)|Go]] language by  Flynn, an open-source platform as a service (PaaS) for running applications in production.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Yegulalp|first1=Serdar|title=Open source Flynn takes the headaches out of app deployment|url=http://www.infoworld.com/article/3101765/open-source-tools/open-source-flynn-takes-the-headaches-out-of-app-deployment.html|website=www.Infoworld.com|publisher=IDG|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Security – Flynn|url=https://flynn.io/docs/security|website=flynn.io|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=flynn/go-tuf|url=https://github.com/flynn/go-tuf#install|website=www.github.com|publisher=GitHub, Inc.|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref> Implementations of TUF have also been written in [https://www.well-typed.com/blog/2015/07/hackage-security-alpha/ Haskell], [[Ruby (programming language)|Ruby]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Securing RubyGems with TUF, Part 1|url=https://medium.com/square-corner-blog/securing-rubygems-with-tuf-part-1-d374fdd05d85|last1=Shay|first1=Xavier|publisher=Medium.com|date=6 December 2013|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> and [https://github.com/heartsucker/rust-tuf Rust].

One of the more significant earlier adoptions of TUF in the [[open-source]] community was by Docker Content Trust,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Monica|first1=Diogo|title=Introducing Docker Content Trust – Docker Blog|url=https://blog.docker.com/2015/08/content-trust-docker-1-8/|website=Blog.Docker.com|publisher=Docker|accessdate=2 October 2016|date=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Docker Content Trust Protects Integrity of Dockerized Content|url=http://www.cioreview.com/news/docker-content-trust-protects-integrity-of-dockerized-content-nid-8372-cid-92.html|website=www.CIOReview.com|publisher=CIO Review|accessdate=2 October 2016}}</ref> an implementation of the Notary project from [[Docker, Inc.|Docker]] that deploys Linux containers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fulton III|first1=Scott M.|title=Docker: With Content Trust, You Can Run Containers on Untrusted Networks – The New Stack|url=http://thenewstack.io/docker-content-trust-can-run-containers-untrusted-networks/|website=TheNewStack.io|publisher=The New Stack|accessdate=3 October 2016|date=12 August 2015}}</ref> Notary, which is built on TUF, can both certify the validity of the sources of Docker images, and encrypt the contents of those images.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vaughan-Nichols|first1=Steven J.|title=Docker 1.8 adds serious container security ZDNet|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/docker-1-8-adds-serious-container-security/|website=ZDNet|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref> In October 2017, Notary and TUF were both adopted as hosted projects by the [[Linux Foundation]] as part of its Cloud Native Computing Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thenewstack.io/cncf-brings-security-cloud-native-stack-notary-tuf-adoption/|title=CNCF Brings Security to the Cloud Native Stack with Notary, TUF Adoption|last1=Jackson|first1=Joab|publisher=The New Stack|date=24 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enterprisecloudnews.com/author.asp?section_id=571&doc_id=737560|title=Cloud Native Computing Foundation Adopts 2 Security Projects |last1=Ferguson|first1=Scott|publisher=Enterprise Cloud News|date=24 October 2017}}</ref>

As of early 2018, the list of tech companies and organizations using TUF in production included DigitalOcean,<ref>{{cite web|title=digitalcoean.com|url=https://www.digitalocean.com/|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
LEAP,<ref>{{cite web|title=New releases for a new year| url=https://leap.se/en/2014/darkest-night/|publisher=Leap Encryption Access Project|date=23 December 2014|accessdate=19 October 2017}}</ref> Kolide,<ref>{{cite web|title=Kolide Updater|url=https://github.com/kolide/updater/blob/master/README.md|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
Cloudflare,<ref>{{cite web|title=A container identity bootstrapping tool|url=https://blog.cloudflare.com/pal-a-container-identity-bootstrapping-tool/|last1=Sullivan|first1=Nick|publisher=Cloudflare blog|date=3 July 2017|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> and VMware.<ref>{{cite web|title=VMware websitel|url=https://www.vmware.com/ |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> A full list of current and in-process integrations can be found on the [https://theupdateframework.github.io/ TUF website].

In 2017, an adaptation of this technology called [https://uptane.github.io/index.html Uptane], designed to protect computing units on automobiles, was named one of the top security inventions for 2017 by [[Popular Science]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Year's Most Important Innovations in Security|url=https://www.popsci.com/top-security-innovations-2017|last1=Atherton|first1=Kelsey D.|last2=Feltman|first2=Rachel|publisher=Popular Science|date=17 October 2017}}</ref>

==References==
{{Reflist|30em}}

==External links==
* [https://theupdateframework.github.io/ TUF website]
* [https://github.com/theupdateframework/tuf/ TUF Repository: A framework for securing software update systems]

===Selected publications===
* '''17th ACM Computer and Communications Security Conference''' (4-8 October 2010) Samuel, J., Mathewson, N.,  Cappos, J., and Dingledine, R., [http://delivery.acm.org/10.1145/1870000/1866315/p61-samuel.pdfip=216.165.95.165&id=1866315&acc=ACTIVE%20SERVICE&key=36E5A5D4E382B3FA%2E36E5A5D4E382B3FA%2E4D4702B0C3E38B35%2E4D4702B0C3E38B35&__acm__=1516316594_bb78f7220b15460e71e429beb419bb15 ''Survivable Key Compromise in Software Update Systems'']
* '''13th USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI ’16)'''(16-18 March 2016) Kuppusamy,T.K., Torres-Arias, S., Diaz, V. and Cappos, J. [https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/nsdi16/nsdi16-paper-kuppusamy.pdf ''Diplomat: Using Delegations to Protect Community Repositories'']
* '''The 2017 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (USENIX ATC 2017)''' (16–18 March 20167) Kuppusamy,T.K., Diaz, V. and Cappos, J. [https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/atc17/atc17-kuppusamy.pdf ''Mercury: Bandwidth-Effective Prevention of Rollback Attacks Against Community Repositories'']

'''The Update Framework (TUF)''' is a [[software framework]] designed to protect mechanisms that automatically identify and download updates to software.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Update Framework Specification|url=https://github.com/theupdateframework/specification/blob/master/tuf-spec.md#1-introduction|publisher=SSL NYU Tandon|last1=Diaz |display-authors=etal |first1=Vladimir|version= V.1.0|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref> It consists of a set of [[software libraries]], file formats, and utilities that can authenticate files and images before they are downloaded. Content|url=http://www.cioreview.com/news/docker-content-trust-protects-integrity-of-dockerized-content-nid-8372-cid-92.html|website=www.CIOReview.com|publisher=CIO Review|accessdate=2 October 2016}}</ref> an implementation of the Notary project from [[Docker, Inc.|Docker]] that deploys Linux containers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fulton III|first1=Scott M.|title=Docker: With Content Trust, You Can Run Containers on Untrusted Networks – The New Stack|url=http://thenewstack.io/docker-content-trust-can-run-containers-untrusted-networks/|website=TheNewStack.io|publisher=The New Stack|accessdate=3 October 2016|date=12 August 2015}}</ref> Notary, which is built on TUF, can both certify the validity of the sources of Docker images, and encrypt the contents of those images.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vaughan-Nichols|first1=Steven J.|title=Docker 1.8 adds serious container security ZDNet|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/docker-1-8-adds-serious-container-security/|website=ZDNet|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref> In October 2017, Notary and TUF were both adopted as hosted projects by the [[Linux Foundation]] as part of its Cloud Native Computing Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thenewstack.io/cncf-brings-security-cloud-native-stack-notary-tuf-adoption/|title=CNCF Brings Security to the Cloud Native Stack with Notary, TUF Adoption|last1=Jackson|first1=Joab|publisher=The New Stack|date=24 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enterprisecloudnews.com/author.asp?section_id=571&doc_id=737560|title=Cloud Native Computing Foundation Adopts 2 Security Projects |last1=Ferguson|first1=Scott|publisher=Enterprise Cloud News|date=24 October 2017}}</ref>

As of early 2018, the list of tech companies and organizations using TUF in production included DigitalOcean,<ref>{{cite web|title=digitalcoean.com|url=https://www.digitalocean.com/|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
LEAP,<ref>{{cite web|title=New releases for a new year| url=https://leap.se/en/2014/darkest-night/|publisher=Leap Encryption Access Project|date=23 December 2014|accessdate=19 October 2017}}</ref> Kolide,<ref>{{cite web|title=Kolide Updater|url=https://github.com/kolide/updater/blob/master/README.md|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
Cloudflare,<ref>{{cite web|title=A container identity bootstrapping tool|url=https://blog.cloudflare.com/pal-a-container-identity-bootstrapping-tool/|last1=Sullivan|first1=Nick|publisher=Cloudflare blog|date=3 July 2017|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> and VMware.<ref>{{cite web|title=VMware websitel|url=https://www.vmware.com/ |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> A full list of current and in-process integrations can be found on the [https://theupdateframework.github.io/ TUF website].

In 2017, an adaptation of this technology called [https://uptane.github.io/index.html Uptane], designed to protect computing units on automobiles, was named one of the top security inventions for 2017 by [[Popular Science]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Year's Most Important Innovations in Security|url=https://www.popsci.com/top-security-innovations-2017|last1=Atherton|first1=Kelsey D.|last2=Feltman|first2=Rachel|publisher=Popular Science|date=17 October 2017}}</ref>

column3: is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese

column1: ''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish
column4: Ornate Butterfly
column5: Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish|Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish|Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler
column6: Jennifer L.
column7: and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”
column8: but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish
column9: it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon
column10: which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish|Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these
column11: they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout
column2: and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\">Adam
column3: T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour''

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon|lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\" />. On the other hand
column4: and live in the arms of branching corals for protection <ref name=\":0\" />. Once juveniles reach breeding age
column5: they form pairs <ref name=\":0\" />. It is uncommon to find adult ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'''  without a mate. Pairs also establish a \"home range\" where you will likely always find them <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are monogamous and pair-forming coral reef fish. Many ornate butterflyfish mate for life. Spawning activity occurs at different times depending on each biome. Tropical spawning peaks in winter and early spring
column2: while temperate spawning occurs in midsummer <ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web|url=https://animaldiversity.org/accounts/Chaetodontidae/|title=Chaetodontidae (Butterflyfishes)|last=Weinheimer|first=Monica|last2=Jonna|first2=R. Jamil|website=Animal Diversity Web|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>. Spawning occurs at dusk and eggs are released and fertilized in the water column <ref name=\":7\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics|tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]]
column4: North to Southern [[Japan]]
column5: South to Lord Howe
column6: and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández
column7: Sebastián
column8: et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quarters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut|Hsu
column9: Kui-Ching; Chen
column10: Jeng-Ping & Shao
column11: Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine
column12: inshore
column13: tropical (30°N - 30°S
column14: 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers
column15: R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada
column16: Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile
column2: benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms
column3: unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett
column4: M. S.
column5: Wilson
column6: S. K.
column7: & Baird
column8: A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology''
column10: 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing
column11: pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however
column12: by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish
column2: specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish
column4: following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al.
column5: revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growth<ref name=\":6\">Brooker
column2: R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6'''
column3: 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).</ref>. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development<ref name=\":6\" />. Coral reef communities provide shelter
column4: and food resources for Butterflyfish<ref name=\":6\" />. However
column5: the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish
column6: as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

column1: ''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species
column2: which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske
column4: August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish|Chaetodon austriacus]]''
column5: ''[[Eastern triangle butterflyfish|C. baronessa]]''
column6: [[Bluelashed butterflyfish|''C. bennetti''
column7: ]] ''[[Chaetodon larvatus|C. larvatus]]''
column8: ''[[Oval butterflyfish|C. lunulatus]]''
column9: [[Scrawled butterflyfish|''C. meyeri''
column10: ]] ''[[Eightband butterflyfish|C. octofasiatus]]''
column11: ''[[Chaetodon rainfordi|C. rainfordi]]
column12: '' and ''[[Melon butterflyfish|C. trifasicatus]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thesprucepets.com/feeding-profile-butterflyfish-family-chaetodontidae-2920779|title=What to Feed Your Butterflyfish|website=The Spruce Pets|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores
column13: which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)|coral polyps]]
column14: tentacles of [[Sabellidae|feather dusters]] and [[Spirobranchus giganteus|Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore
column15: butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral
column16: and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake
column18: turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are one of the most popular tropical fishes with divers and aquarists <ref name=\":7\" />. However
column2: ornate butterflyfish are nearly impossible to successfully keep in captivity because they are obligate corallivores <ref name=\":7\" />.

column5: Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish|Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish|Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout
column2: and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\">Adam
column3: T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour''

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon|lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\" />. On the other hand
column4: and live in the arms of branching corals for protection <ref name=\":0\" />. Once juveniles reach breeding age
column5: they form pairs <ref name=\":0\" />. It is uncommon to find adult ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'''  without a mate. Pairs also establish a \"home range\" where you will likely always find them <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are monogamous and pair-forming coral reef fish. Many ornate butterflyfish mate for life. Spawning activity occurs at different times depending on each biome. Tropical spawning peaks in winter and early spring
column2: while temperate spawning occurs in midsummer <ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web|url=https://animaldiversity.org/accounts/Chaetodontidae/|title=Chaetodontidae (Butterflyfishes)|last=Weinheimer|first=Monica|last2=Jonna|first2=R. Jamil|website=Animal Diversity Web|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>. Spawning occurs at dusk and eggs are released and fertilized in the water column <ref name=\":7\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics|tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]]
column4: North to Southern [[Japan]]
column5: South to Lord Howe
column6: and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile
column2: benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms
column3: unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett

column10: 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing
column11: pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however
column12: by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish
column2: specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish
column4: following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al.
column5: revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growth<ref name=\":6\">Brooker
column2: R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6'''
column3: 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).</ref>. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development<ref name=\":6\" />. Coral reef communities provide shelter
column4: and food resources for Butterflyfish<ref name=\":6\" />. However
column5: the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish
column6: as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

column1: ''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species
column2: which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske

Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish|Chaetodon austriacus]]''
column5: ''[[Eastern triangle butterflyfish|C. baronessa]]''
column6: [[Bluelashed butterflyfish|''C. bennetti''
column7: ]] ''[[Chaetodon larvatus|C. larvatus]]''
column8: ''[[Oval butterflyfish|C. lunulatus]]''
column9: [[Scrawled butterflyfish|''C. meyeri''
column10: ]] ''[[Eightband butterflyfish|C. octofasiatus]]''
column11: ''[[Chaetodon rainfordi|C. rainfordi]]
column12: '' and ''[[Melon butterflyfish|C. trifasicatus]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thesprucepets.com/feeding-profile-butterflyfish-family-chaetodontidae-2920779|title=What to Feed Your Butterflyfish|website=The Spruce Pets|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores
column13: which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)|coral polyps]]
column14: tentacles of [[Sabellidae|feather dusters]] and [[Spirobranchus giganteus|Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore
column15: butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral
column16: and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake
column18: turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are one of the most popular tropical fishes with divers and aquarists <ref name=\":7\" />. However
column2: ornate butterflyfish are nearly impossible to successfully keep in captivity because they are obligate corallivores <ref name=\":7\" />.

column5: and remains the only officially issued work by the band.

column3: as lead singer. Gypp also played abroad and became popular in Germany's North Rhine-Westphalia area thanks to their live performances. Gypp issued one 3-song 7-inch EP in 1978
column4: but their music was out of step with the punk-oriented trends of the UK music scene at the time and the EP received a negative review in the ''[[New Musical Express]].''  Demoralised
column5: Newell left the band. By his own account
column6: he then became a \"musical recluse\"
column7: staying in the studio and creating new songs but not playing live gigs for many years.

column2: Newell led a four-piece rock combo called '''The Stray Trolleys'''. They recorded material in 1979 and 1980
column3: but it was not released until after the band had broken up.

column2: Newell issued his first solo single (\"Young Jobless\" b/w \"Sylvie in Toytown\") on vinyl in 1980. By the end of 1980
column3: he was collaborating with Lawrence \"Lol\" Elliot as '''The Cleaners from Venus'''
column4: a band that mostly released their work on cassettes outside the traditional music distribution channels.

column2: The Cleaners from Venus had evolved into a band with a floating line-up that featured Newell as its only constant. The band still primarily issued material on cassette
column3: got signed to the West German independent label Modell Records for one vinyl album (''Under Wartime Conditions'') and ultimately to the German leg of [[RCA]] Records which released two albums (''Going to England''
column4: ''Town and Country'').

column1: [[Giles Smith]] joined Newell as the only other official member of Cleaners From Venus between 1986 and 1988
column3: Newell returned to performing live under The Cleaners of<!-- Is \"of\" deliberate here
column4: or just a typo for \"from\"? --> Venus banner. As well
column5: while regularly releasing Cleaners From Venus material on cassette
column6: through the 1980s Newell also occasionally released cassette singles and albums under his own name. On these solo releases he was usually the only musician.

column1: In spring 1988 Newell and Nelson (Peter Nice) formed the [[Musical_ensemble#Two_parts|duo]] '''The Brotherhood of Lizards'''
column2: self-releasing the [[Mini-LP|mini-album]] ''The Brotherhood of Lizards'' that same year
column3: followed by the album ''Lizardland'' released on [[Independent record label|independent label]] Deltic Records in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Newell |first1=Martin |title=Lizard Tails -- Martin Looks Back |url=http://www.stevedix.de/newell/overview.html |website=Martin Newell's website |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> To support the album the duo embarked on a [[Environmentally friendly|eco-friendly]] promotional tour
column4: cycling over 1000 miles across southern England between October 1989 and February 1990 to make local radio appearances and and do local newspaper interviews
column5: while also [[Street performance|busking]] and performing gigs. The uniqueness of this \"green tour\" caught the attention of the [[Media of the United Kingdom|mainstream media]] with the duo making half a dozen televison appearances
column6: and interviews with them appeared in the [[NME]]
column7: [[Melody Maker]]
column8: [[The Guardian]]
column9: [[The Independent]]
column10: [[The Mail on Sunday]] and [[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]. On completion of the tour Nelson was recruited as the replacement bass player for the band [[New Model Army (band)|New Model Army]] and the Brotherhood of Lizards disbanded.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Newell |first1=Martin |title=Martin Newell's Illustrated Tour Diaries |url=http://www.stevedix.de/newell/lizarddiaries.html |website=Martin Newell's website |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |last1=Frometa |first1=RJ |title=Captured Tracks Releases Reissue Of Brotherhood of Lizards “Lizardland” TODAY |url=https://ventsmagazine.com/2016/08/19/captured-tracks-releases-reissue-brotherhood-lizards-lizardland-today/ |website=Vents Magazine |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>

column2: Newell began working primarily as a solo artist with more conventional production values. His first non-cassette solo album
column4: was produced by [[XTC]]'s [[Andy Partridge]]
column5: and was a critical success.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} Commercially
column6: it remains his most popular and successful album.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}}  It was followed by three more albums (''The Off White Album''
column7: produced by [[Louis Philippe (musician)|Louis Philippe]]
column8: ''The Spirit Cage'' and ''Radio Autumn Attic'') and an EP (''Songs from the Station Hotel'') that continued to explore the same subject matter as ''Englishman''
column9: including the charms of rural or small-town English life and portraits of characters and scenes.

column1: Newell has also made live appearances with The Cleaners from Venus and The Stray Trolleys in the 1990s and beyond
column2: and has issued several post-1993 live recordings with these bands. However
column3: studio releases credited to these groups post-1993 are actually all CD reissues of pre-1993 material previously released only on cassette. In addition
column4: Gypp played reunion gigs in 1996
column5: and live Gypp material – as well as Gypp demos recorded in the late 1970s – have now been officially issued on CD.

column1: In 2004 Newell released an album of light jazz songs
column2: ''The Light Programme''. The album was not particularly successful commercially but his next album ''A Summer Tamarind'' returned to his usual style and was much more warmly received.

column1: In late 2005 the British singer [[Richard Shelton (actor)|Richard Shelton]] released a jazz vocal album called ''Top Cat'' with five Newell compositions. Newell's songs have also been recorded by Miki Huber
column4: [[R. Stevie Moore]] and [[Alphaville (group)|Alphaville]].

column1: Newell is better known to some as a poet and author; he has released several volumes of poetry (often in collaboration with [[James Dodds]]) and a memoir
column3: about his youth and his days in Plod. In 2007 he released a volume of reminiscences
column4: anecdotes and historical information about his beloved Wivenhoe. He is also a weekly contributor of poetry to ''[[The Sunday Express]]
column5: '' He now writes a weekly column for the East Anglian Daily Times (for which he won columnist of the year in the EDF/ East of England Media Awards in January 2010)
column6: performs annually at the [[Essex Book Festival]] and occasionally  issues spoken word recordings of his poems.

column3: and remains the only officially issued work by the band.
as lead singer. Gypp also played abroad and became popular in Germany's North Rhine-Westphalia area thanks to their live performances. Gypp issued one 3-song 7-inch EP in 1978
column4: but their music was out of step with the punk-oriented trends of the UK music scene at the time and the EP received a negative review in the ''[[New Musical Express]].''  Demoralised
column5: Newell left the band. By his own account
column6: he then became a \"musical recluse\"
column7: staying in the studio and creating new songs but not playing live gigs for many years.

column2: Newell led a four-piece rock combo called '''The Stray Trolleys'''. They recorded material in 1979 and 1980
column3: but it was not released until after the band had broken up.

column2: Newell issued his first solo single (\"Young Jobless\" b/w \"Sylvie in Toytown\") on vinyl in 1980. By the end of 1980
column3: he was collaborating with Lawrence \"Lol\" Elliot as '''The Cleaners from Venus'''
column4: a band that mostly released their work on cassettes outside the traditional music distribution channels.

column2: The Cleaners from Venus had evolved into a band with a floating line-up that featured Newell as its only constant. The band still primarily issued material on cassette
column3: got signed to the West German independent label Modell Records for one vinyl album (''Under Wartime Conditions'') and ultimately to the German leg of [[RCA]] Records which released two albums (''Going to England''
column4: ''Town and Country'').

column1: [[Giles Smith]] joined Newell as the only other official member of Cleaners From Venus between 1986 and 1988
column3: Newell returned to performing live under The Cleaners of<!-- Is \"of\" deliberate here
column4: or just a typo for \"from\"? --> Venus banner. As well
column5: while regularly releasing Cleaners From Venus material on cassette
column6: through the 1980s Newell also occasionally released cassette singles and albums under his own name. On these solo releases he was usually the only musician.

column1: In spring 1988 Newell and Nelson (Peter Nice) formed the [[Musical_ensemble#Two_parts|duo]] '''The Brotherhood of Lizards'''
column2: self-releasing the [[Mini-LP|mini-album]] ''The Brotherhood of Lizards'' that same year
column3: followed by the album ''Lizardland'' released on [[Independent record label|independent label]] Deltic Records in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Newell |first1=Martin |title=Lizard Tails -- Martin Looks Back |url=http://www.stevedix.de/newell/overview.html |website=Martin Newell's website |accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> To support the album the duo embarked on a [[Environmentally friendly|eco-friendly]] promotional tour
column4: cycling over 1000 miles across southern England between October 1989 and February 1990 to make local radio appearances and and do local newspaper interviews
column5: while also [[Street performance|busking]] and performing gigs. The uniqueness of this \"green tour\" caught the attention of the [[Media of the United Kingdom|mainstream media]] with the duo making half a dozen televison appearances
column6: and interviews with them appearing in the [[NME]]
column7: [[Melody Maker]]
column8: [[The Guardian]]
column9: [[The Independent]]
column10: [[The Mail on Sunday]] and [[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]. '''''Cheer''''' is an American television [[docuseries]] airing on [[Netflix]] starting in January 2020.<ref name=\:3\">{{Cite web|url=https://popculture.com/sports/2020/01/12/cheer-season-1-reviews-for-netflix-docuseries-are-in/|title='Cheer' Season 1: Reviews for the Netflix Docuseries Are In|last=Newby|first=John|date=January 12
column5: 2020|website=[[Pop Culture]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 13
column6: 2020}}</ref> The six-part series follows the nationally ranked 40-member [[Navarro College]] Bulldogs Cheer Team from [[Corsicana
column7: Texas]]
column8: under the direction of coach [[Monica Aldama]]
column9: as they prepare to compete in the National Cheerleading Championship held annually in Daytona
column10: Florida.<ref name=\":4\" /><ref name=\":10\" /> The episodes focus especially on five individual Cheer Team members and include elements of the history of [[cheerleading]]
column11: including the formation of the [[National Cheerleaders Association]] (NCA).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cinemablend.com/television/2488323/netflix-cheer-cast-how-gabi-butler-lexi-morgan-feel-about-cheerleading-documentary-series|title=Netflix's Cheer: How Gabi Butler

column1: Director [[Greg Whiteley]] came across [[Competitive Cheerleading|competitive cheerleading]] while filming for his football television series ''[[Last Chance U]]''.<ref name=\":12\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.distractify.com/p/coach-monica-cheer-netflix|title=Meet Monica
column2: the Coaching Legend on Netflix's New Docuseries 'Cheer'|last=Cacich|first=Allison|date=January 8
column4: 2020}}</ref> He found the cheerleaders to be better athletes
column5: and highly competitive.<ref name=\":12\" />

column4: Texas]]
column5: about fifty miles south of Dallas
column6: ” has a Cheer Team coached by [[Monica Aldama]] who graduated from [[Corsicana High School]]
column7: earned a degree in Finance at the [[University of Texas at Austin]]
column8: then a [[Master of Business Administration]] at the [[University of Texas at Tyler]]; she was a cheerleader in college;<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.messenger-inquirer.com/features/venue/hard-working-cheerleaders-have-long-deserved-cheer/article_6f9a3382-a794-53f5-b2f8-e8eeb3cf738c.html|title=Hard-working cheerleaders have long deserved 'Cheer'|last=Stuever|first=Hank|date=January 10
column9: 2020|website=[[The Washington Post]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 15
column10: 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latintimes.com/monica-aldama-5-things-about-coach-netflixs-cheer-454192|title=Monica Aldama: 5 Things About The Coach In Netflix's 'Cheer'|last=Burog|first=Vianne|date=January 10
column11: 2020|website=[[Latin Times]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 15
column12: 2020}}</ref> because of her devotion to her extended Texan family
column13: and her and her husband ‘s desire to raise their children with their families
column14: she accepted the position of cheerleading coach at [[Navarro College]]. She built the program starting in 2000 from the ground up making it into the best in the nation.<ref name=\":3\" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://knue.com/navarro-college-cheer-team-on-netflix-in-episode-of-cheer/|title=Navarro College Cheer Team On Netflix In Episode Of 'Cheer'|last=Larry|first=Lucky|date=January 10
column15: 2020|website=[[KNUE]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 14
column16: 2020}}</ref><ref name=\":10\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/tv/2020/01/09/cheer-netflix-how-change-your-mind-cheerleading/2849062001/|title=Review: How Netflix's superb 'Cheer' dispels your assumptions about cheerleading|last=Lawler|first=Kelly|date=January 9

column2: ''Cheer'' has a “100 percent rating from critics
column3: and 93 percent from audience members on ''[[Rotten Tomatoes]]''”.<ref name=\":3\" /> ''[[The Washington Post]]’''s [[Hank Stuever]] wrote
column4: \"''Cheer'' quickly and effortlessly becomes all-consuming for the viewer. Whiteley superbly structures the story through six episodes to heighten the anxiety as the competition nears.\"<ref name=\":3\" /> [[Vulture (magazine)|Vulture]]’s Jen Chaney stated
column5: “while it depicts plenty of conflicts and disagreements between the cheerleaders at Navarro College in Corsicana
column6: Texas
column7: it’s an ultimately more uplifting show that uses cheer as a prism through which to explore overcoming all kinds of obstacles.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vulture.com/2020/01/dare-me-cheer-review.html|title=Welcome to TV's Cheer-ocracy|last=Chaney|first=Jen|date=January 8
column8: 2020|website=[[Vulture (magazine)]]|language=en-us|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 15

column1: In January 2020 the Navarro Cheer Team with coach Monica appeared on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]''
column2: and performed a full routine; [[Ellen DeGeneres]] presented them with $20
column3: 000 toward their fundraising goal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/caseyrackham/navarro-cheer-ellen-performance|title=The Navarro Team From \"Cheer\" Performed On \"Ellen\" And They Were So Good|last=Rackham|first=Casey|date=January 24
column4: 2020|website=BuzzFeed|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 26
column5: 2020}}</ref> The January 25
column6: 2020 episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' had a sketch spoofing ''Cheer'' with guest host [[Adam Driver]] as one of the coaches apparently unconcerned as team members want to make the mat—the twenty chosen for the finals—so bad they want to cheer despite near-catastrophic injuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ftw.usatoday.com/2020/01/saturday-night-live-cheer-netflix|title=SNL spoofs Netflix's 'Cheer
column7: ' and the director responded with jokes on Twitter|last=McKenna|first=Henry|date=January 26
column8: 2020|website=[[For The Win (USA Today)|For The Win]]|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 27
column9: 2020}}</ref> In late January 2020
column10: the ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]'' featured a spoof commercial about mat talk
column11: the boisterous positivity sideline cheers that teammates do for the performing members—for which [[Jerry Harris (television personality)|Jerry Harris]] was singled-out during the series as excelling in—for their performance.<ref name=\":0\" /> The conceit was a new booster Mat Talk for Regular People program whereby the Navarro Cheer Team members would praise everyday people for mundane activities
column12: and featured [[La'Darius Marshall]]
column13: Harris
column14: and [[Gabi Butler]] cheering people on
column15: with coach [[Monica Aldama]] available for a Booster Shot.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite episode|title=Edie Falco
