column4:
{{Use British English|date=July 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Dave Cornthwaite | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = David Cornthwaite | birth_date = | birth_place = | alma mater = [[Stamford School]], [[University of Swansea]] | residence = [[London]], England | occupation = [[Adventurer]]
[[Explorer]]
[[Motivational speaking|Motivational speaker]]
[[Author]] | spouse = Em Karembo Taylor (m. 2018) | children = | parents = | website = [http://www.davecornthwaite.com davecornthwaite.com] | footnotes = }} '''David \Dave\" Cornthwaite''' is an [[English people|English]] [[adventurer]]
column5: [[writer]] and filmmaker. He is best known for his Expedition1000 project
column6: a plan to undertake 25 separate journeys of 1000 miles or more
column7: each using a different form of non-motorised transport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/blog/2014/07/23/meet-a-traveller-dave-cornthwaite-record-breaking-adventurer-and-overland-traveller/|title=Meet a traveller: Dave Cornthwaite
column8: record-breaking adventurer and overland traveller|author=Lonely Planet|work=lonelyplanet.com|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"e1000\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.davecornthwaite.com/journeys/4578966999 |title=Archived copy |access-date=14 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030022705/http://www.davecornthwaite.com/journeys/4578966999 |archive-date=30 October 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

column1: Cornthwaite was born in England and attended [http://www.dukeofkentschool.org.uk/ Duke of Kent School] in Surrey and then [[Stamford School]] in [[Lincolnshire]]. After finishing his high school education
column2: he travelled to [[Uganda]] as a volunteer in a [[gap year]] teaching scheme organised by Africa & Asia Venture. Cornthwaite called this \"his first taste of adventure\".{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
Cornthwaite skateboarded along Britain's [[Land's End to John o'Groats|End-to-end]] route from [[John O'Groats]] to [[Lands End]]
column3: a distance of {{convert|1442|km|mi}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/south_west/4788111.stm |title=UK | Wales | South West Wales | Skateboarder's Down Under attempt |publisher=BBC News |date=13 August 2006 |accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref> The journey took 34 days. Three rest days were required when Cornthwaite developed severe [[blisters]]. On 2 June 2006
column4: Cornthwaite completed the journey
column5: becoming the first person to do so on a skateboard. This journey and another in [[Australia]]<ref>Gibson J.  [http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/but-skate-theres-more/2006/08/22/1156012526668.html \"But skate
column6: there's more ... 6000k\"] Sydney Morning Herald website
column7: Sydney 22 August 2006. Accessed 10 August 2015.</ref> were made in association with charities including The Lowe Syndrome Trust
column8: [[Link Community Development]] and [[Sailability Australia]].<ref>[http://www.lowetrust.com/media/pressrelease.boardfree.shtml \"World Skateboarding Distance Record for Lowe Syndrome
column9: Dec '06.\"] Lowe Syndrome UK website 2006. Accessed 10 August 2015.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2006/12/17/chairman-of-the-skateboard-470368/|title=Chairman of the skateboard – Metro News|author=|work=Metro.co.uk|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref>

column1: Expedition1000 is Cornthwaite's 12-year career project to make twenty-five journeys of {{convert|1000|mi|km}} or more
column2: each using a different form of non-motorised transport.<ref name=\"e1000\" />
Cornthwaite and Sebastian Terry journeyed {{convert|1400|mi|km}}  from [[Vancouver|Vancouver
column4: Canada
column5: to [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] by [[tandem bicycle]]. Neither had previously ridden a tandem bike.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://maptia.com/davecornthwaite/stories/vancouver-to-vegas-by-tandem|title=Vancouver to Vegas by Tandem|author=|work=Maptia.com|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.davecornthwaite.com/tandem/4579328172 |title=Archived copy |access-date=14 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030043659/http://www.davecornthwaite.com/tandem/4579328172 |archive-date=30 October 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

column3: [[Guinness World Record]]-setting journey down the [[Mississippi River]] from source to sea on a [[Stand up paddle surfing|stand up paddleboard]]. The journey started at Elk Lake
column4: just south of [[Lake Itasca]]
column5: in [[Minnesota]]. The descent of the Mississippi River took 68 days including passage through falls
column6: dams and locks. [[Tropical Storm Lee (2011)|Hurricane Lee]] caused Cornthwaite to leave the water for a time
column7: lengthening the trip to a total of 82 days. Cornthwaite carried all of his provisions by securing them in waterproof bags strapped to the deck of his paddleboard. Cornthwaite's speed depended on that of the [[current (stream)|current]]. The greatest distance covered in one day was {{convert|77|mi|km}}
column8: just upstream of St. Louis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/08/dave-cornthwaite-paddleboarding-mississippi-river_n_952846.html|title=Dave Cornthwaite Paddleboards Down Mississippi River
column9: Gets into Record Books|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref>

column2: in a fifth adventure for Expedition1000
column3: Cornthwaite and a crew of ten sailed from [[Cabo San Lucas]]
column4: [[Mexico]]
column5: to [[Honolulu]]
column6: [[Hawaii]]. The {{convert|3156|mi|km|adj=on}} journey took 17 days. During this time
column7: Cornthwaite and Emily Penn (the program director of Pangaea Explorations) conducted a series of workshops on topics ranging from ocean science to social media to diagnosis of personal happiness and purpose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.active-traveller.com/people/interview-dave-cornthwaite|title=Active-Traveller – Interview: Dave Cornthwaite|author=Mike Walker|work=Active-Traveller|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref>

column4: South Dakota]] towards [[St. Louis]]
column5: [[Missouri]]. He had a support crew of six but pulled his provisions along behind him on a raft. The swim raised funds for CoppaFeel!
column6: a breast cancer awareness organization.<ref>{{cite web|title=Swimming 1
column7: 000 Miles down the Missouri River|url=https://www.gapyear.com/features/188357/swimming-1000-miles-down-the-missouri-river|website=Gapyear.com|accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref>

column2: Cornthwaite and Sebastian Terry became the first people to cross [[Lake Geneva]] on stand up paddleboards. They made the {{convert|87|km|mi|adj=on|order=flip}} journey in less than two days. Cornthwaite produced a documentary [[DVD]] of the expedition entitled ''Lake Geneva Crossing''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wideworldmag.com/features/great-big-paddle-across-lake-geneva |accessdate=4 July 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119220147/http://www.wideworldmag.com/features/great-big-paddle-across-lake-geneva |archivedate=19 January 2011 }}</ref>

column3: Somerset|Bath]] to beneath the [[Tower Bridge]] in [[London]]. The five-day journey
column4: which finished on 8 June 2010
column5: [[World Oceans Day]]
column6: was a celebration of Britain's inland waterways.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bristol.indymedia.org.uk/article/690165?show_preferences=true |title=network23 | a network for free sites |publisher=Bristol.indymedia.org.uk |accessdate=29 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112110321/https://bristol.indymedia.org.uk/article/690165?show_preferences=true |archive-date=12 November 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

column1: Cornthwaite writes about his journeys in a personal [[blog]]
column2: in [[freelance]] magazine contributions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mensfitness.co.uk/exercise/sports/6631/adventure_holidays_on_a_budget.html |title=Adventure holidays on a budget | Men's Fitness UK |publisher=Mensfitness.co.uk |date=28 March 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref> and books.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cornthwaite|first=Dave|title=Board Free|year=2008|publisher=Portico|isbn=978-1-906032-19-7|pages=279}}</ref>
based on his world-record-breaking skate across Australia was published in 2008. It was entitled ''BoardFree: The Story of an Incredible Skateboard Journey Across Australia''. In 2008
column3: Cornthwaite wrote a book about dating entitled ''Date: Confessions of a Temporary Serial Dater''.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}

column1: Cornthwaite works as a [[motivational speaker]] at corporations
column2: schools and other organizations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adventuretravellive.com/visitor_information_show_features_explorer_workshop.php |title=Adventure Travel Show 2016 :: Visitor Information Show Features Explorer Worksho |publisher=Adventuretravellive.com |accessdate=29 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117034300/http://www.adventuretravellive.com/visitor_information_show_features_explorer_workshop.php |archive-date=17 November 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.escapethecity.org/esc-wednesdays/marchs-esc-wednesday-dave-cornthwaite/ |title=Come to March's Esc Wednesday: Dave Cornthwaite - Escape the City |publisher=Blog.escapethecity.org |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110704013031/http://blog.escapethecity.org/esc-wednesdays/marchs-esc-wednesday-dave-cornthwaite/ |archive-date=4 July 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2011
column3: Cornthwaite gave a speech for the [[TEDx Youth]] event in [[Bath
column4: Somerset|Bath]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j4uPOnP7r-g |title=TEDxYouth@Bath - Dave Cornthwaite - The philosophy of adventure |publisher=YouTube |date=13 July 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref>

column1: Cornthwaite makes documentaries about his expeditions and those of other British adventurers. Cornthwaite is an ambassador for The Blue Project
column2: a climate and oceans project that brings together elite sports men and women to promote sport
column3: healthy living and a clean environment.

column1: Cornthwaite married fellow adventurer and expedition leader Emma Karembo Taylor in September 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/DaveCorn/status/1037944188606799872 |website=Dave Cornthwaite on Twitter |accessdate=14 September 2018}}</ref>

column2: British adventurer and world record breaker
English survival expert and TV presenter

column1: Cornthwaite works as a [[motivational speaker]] at corporations
column2: schools and other organizations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adventuretravellive.com/visitor_information_show_features_explorer_workshop.php |title=Adventure Travel Show 2016 :: Visitor Information Show Features Explorer Worksho |publisher=Adventuretravellive.com |accessdate=29 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117034300/http://www.adventuretravellive.com/visitor_information_show_features_explorer_workshop.php |archive-date=17 November 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.escapethecity.org/esc-wednesdays/marchs-esc-wednesday-dave-cornthwaite/ |title=Come to March's Esc Wednesday: Dave Cornthwaite - Escape the City |publisher=Blog.escapethecity.org |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110704013031/http://blog.escapethecity.org/esc-wednesdays/marchs-esc-wednesday-dave-cornthwaite/ |archive-date=4 July 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2011
column3: Cornthwaite gave a speech for the [[TEDx Youth]] event in [[Bath
column4: Somerset|Bath]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j4uPOnP7r-g |title=TEDxYouth@Bath - Dave Cornthwaite - The philosophy of adventure |publisher=YouTube |date=13 July 2013 |accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref>

column1: Cornthwaite makes documentaries about his expeditions and those of other British adventurers. Cornthwaite is an ambassador for The Blue Project
column2: a climate and oceans project that brings together elite sports men and women to promote sport
column3: healthy living and a clean environment.

column1: Cornthwaite married fellow adventurer and expedition leader Emma Karembo Taylor in September 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/DaveCorn/status/1037944188606799872 |website=Dave Cornthwaite on Twitter |accessdate=14 September 2018}}</ref>

column2: British adventurer and world record breaker
English survival expert and TV presenter

Green and white |website = {{URL|http://www.uog.edu}} }} '''University of Guam''' ({{lang-ch|Unibetsedåt Guåhan}}) ('''U.O.G.''') is a public [[land-grant university]] in [[Mangilao, Guam]]. It is accredited by the [[Western Association of Schools and Colleges]] and offers thirty-four degree programs at the undergraduate level and eleven master's level programs. Of the university's 3,387 students, 94% are of [[Asian people|Asian]]-[[Pacific Islander]] ethnicity and nearly 72% are full-time (fall 2012 figures). A full-time faculty of about 180 supports the university's mission of \Ina
column5: Diskubre

column7: to Discover
column8: to Serve.\"

column1: University of Guam was founded in 1952 as a two-year teacher-training school known as the '''Territorial College of Guam'''
column2: established by Governor [[Carlton Skinner]].<ref name=sfgate>{{cite web| last = Fagan| first = Kevin| authorlink = | title = Carlton Skinner -- broke racial barriers in Navy| publisher = San Francisco Chronicle| date = 29 August 2004| url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fchronicle%2Farchive%2F2004%2F08%2F29%2FBAG858GD2T1.DTL&type=printable| doi = | accessdate =  5 May 2009}}</ref>  In 1960
column3: the college moved to the present campus in the central district of [[Mangilao
column4: Guam|Mangilao]]. In 1965
column5: the college was accredited as a four-year
column6: degree granting institution. By 1968
column7: enrollment had reached 1
column8: 800 students while staff and faculty totaled more than 130. It was designated as a [[land grant institution]] by the [[United States Congress]] in 1972.

column4:
{{short description|Wikipedia list article}}
The [[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System|San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] (MTS) operate 97 '''bus routes in [[San Diego]]''' and the rest of the southern half of [[San Diego County]], {{As of|2020|April|lc=y}}.<ref name=about>{{cite web | title=About MTS | publisher=[[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] | url=https://www.sdmts.com/about-mts | accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref><ref name=routes>{{cite web | url=https://www.sdmts.com/schedules-real-time-maps-and-routes/bus-routes | title=Bus Routes | publisher=[[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] |accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref>

MTS serves San Diego proper and the surrounding [[East County, San Diego|East County]] and [[South Bay, San Diego|South Bay]] regions,<ref name=mts-map>{{cite web | title=San Diego Regional Transit Map | publisher=[[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] | url=https://www.sdmts.com/sites/default/files/attachments/rtm_sep2019_web_.pdf | date=September 2019 | accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> while the [[North County (San Diego area)|North County]] area sees more frequent and expansive service by the [[North County Transit District]]'s BREEZE bus system.<ref name=nctd-map>{{cite web | title=North County Transit District System Map | publisher=[[North County Transit District]] | url=https://gonctd.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/NCTDSystemMap.pdf | date=October 8, 2017 | accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref>

==List of routes==
The following tables lists the bus routes operated by MTS in San Diego County, {{As of|2019|January|lc=y}}.<ref name=routes/>

{|class=\wikitable plainrowheaders sortable\"

{{short description|Wikipedia list article}}
The [[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System|San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] (MTS) operate 97 '''bus routes in [[San Diego]]''' and the rest of the southern half of [[San Diego County]], {{As of|2020|April|lc=y}}.<ref name=about>{{cite web | title=About MTS | publisher=[[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] | url=https://www.sdmts.com/about-mts | accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref><ref name=routes>{{cite web | url=https://www.sdmts.com/schedules-real-time-maps-and-routes/bus-routes | title=Bus Routes | publisher=[[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] |accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref>

MTS serves San Diego proper and the surrounding [[East County, San Diego|East County]] and [[South Bay, San Diego|South Bay]] regions,<ref name=mts-map>{{cite web | title=San Diego Regional Transit Map | publisher=[[San Diego Metropolitan Transit System]] | url=https://www.sdmts.com/sites/default/files/attachments/rtm_sep2019_web_.pdf | date=September 2019 | accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> while the [[North County (San Diego area)|North County]] area sees more frequent and expansive service by the [[North County Transit District]]'s BREEZE bus system.<ref name=nctd-map>{{cite web | title=North County Transit District System Map | publisher=[[North County Transit District]] | url=https://gonctd.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/NCTDSystemMap.pdf | date=October 8, 2017 | accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref>

==List of routes==
The following tables lists the bus routes operated by MTS in San Diego County, {{As of|2019|January|lc=y}}.<ref name=routes/>

column1: '''''Killa Season''''' is the fifth [[studio album]] by [[Harlem]] rapper [[Cam'ron]]. The album was released on May 16
column3: by [[Diplomat Records]] and [[Asylum Records]]. Cam'ron was also the executive producer of the album. The album received positive reviews but critics found the production and content lesser compared to ''[[Purple Haze (album)|Purple Haze]]''. ''Killa Season'' sold 114
column4: 000 copies in its first week
column5: debuting at number two on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hasty |first=Katie |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/58329/chilis-warm-to-no-1-album-post-again |title=Chili's Warm To No. 1 Album Post Again |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=May 24
column6: 2006 |accessdate=May 14

column1: |rev2Score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref name=\"HHDX\">{{cite magazine|last=Sims |first=Brian |url=https://www.hiphopdx.com/index/reviews/id.637/title.camron-killa-season |title=Cam'ron - Killa Season |magazine=[[HipHopDX]] |publisher=Cheri Media Group |date=May 15

|rev3Score = {{Rating|2.5|4}}<ref name=\"Phoenix\">{{cite news|last=Sylvester |first=Nick |url=http://thephoenix.com/boston/music/15452-camron/ |title=Cam'Ron |newspaper=[[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Phoenix]] |publisher=[[Phoenix Media/Communications Group]] |date=June 20

|rev5Score = 7/10<ref name=\"RR\">{{cite web|last=Juon |first=Steve 'Flash' |url=https://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2006_05_killacd.html |title=Cam'Ron :: Killa Season :: Diplomatic Man/Asylum Records |website=RapReviews |date=May 16

|rev6Score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref name=\"RS\">{{cite magazine|last=Relic |first=Peter |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/camron/albums/album/10346655/review/10480684/killa_season |title=Cam'ron: Killa Season |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]] |date=June 2

|rev7Score = B-<ref name=\"Stylus\">{{cite magazine|last=Greene |first=Jayson |url=http://www.stylusmagazine.com/reviews/camron/killa-season.htm |title=Cam'ron - Killa Season |magazine=[[Stylus Magazine]] |date=May 24

''Killa Season'' garnered a positive reception but [[Music journalism|music critics]] were mixed toward Cam's choices in production and lyrical content compared to ''[[Purple Haze (album)|Purple Haze]]''. Peter Relic of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' found criticism in the album's production and soul samples and Cam's insults towards [[Jay-Z]] but still found it entertaining with its wordplay
column2: saying that \"''Killa Season'' proves Cam'ron can still bring heady verbiage and heat
column3: but it's doubtful Jay-Z is losing much sleep.\"<ref name=\"RS\"/> While also finding the production decent
column4: Brian Sims of ''[[HipHopDX]]'' praised the album's skits and hooks and Cam's delivery for bringing light to creative imagery
column5: saying that \"As an industry veteran
column6: Cam deserves a lot of credit for not using his album to address petty squabbles or provide some pseudo-intellectual autobiography.\"<ref name=\"HHDX\"/> [[AllMusic]] editor David Jeffries said that the album was in need of a rewrite on some tracks but still found it enjoyable with memorable hooks and for showing a vulnerable side in Cam
column7: concluding that \"''Killa Season'' would have benefited from trimming and better planning
column8: but those things are extremely rare in the world of Dipset. Taking that into account
column9: the album is exceptional and a good enough excuse for two more years of mouthing off and starting trouble.\"<ref name=\"AM\"/>

column1: Steve 'Flash' Juon of RapReviews praised the album for continuing ''Purple Haze''{{'}}s formula with tight wordplay and loose soul sample production
column2: despite containing tracks that were Dipset holdovers
column4: \"Nonetheless Cam fans should be happy with ''Killa Season''
column5: an album which continues his recent trend of solid (if somewhat unspectacular) solo CD's.\"<ref name=\"RR\"/> Jayson Greene of ''[[Stylus Magazine]]'' found some of Cam's lyrics humorous at times
column6: but found the production and guest artists lacking in variety in terms of go-to names
column7: concluding with \"Instead
column8: ''Killa Season'' is a retreat
column9: an album to satisfy the converted but one that will keep his mythical status confined to the 12-mile radius of his Manhattan home.\"<ref name=\"Stylus\"/> ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' writer Ryan Dombal felt the album was a disappointment compared to ''Purple Haze''
column10: finding the production lacking in energy and in need of more humorous songs (\"I.B.S.\") then aggressive diss tracks (\"You Gotta Love It\"). Dombal also pointed out that the limited edition of the album contained a DVD that reveals Cam'ron's battle with Jay-Z was all for publicity
column11: concluding that
column12: \"If this underwhelming offering is any indication
column13: such blind self-reference has considerably slowed down Cam'ron's once-unstoppable Dipset Movement.\"<ref name=\"Pitchfork\"/>

column1: | title2 = He Tried to Play Me
| extra5 = Jonathan Dugger a.k.a. \"Peersonile\" for Versatile Music Productions
| extra20 = Jonathan Dugger a.k.a. \"Peersonile\" for Versatile Music Productions

'''''Aphis spiraecola''''' is a species of aphid described in 1914 by Edith Marion Patch.<ref name=\Global Biodiversity Information Facility -  Aphis spiraecola (Patch
column5: 1914)\">{{cite web|url=https://www.gbif.org/species/2072761|title= Aphis spiraecola (Patch
column6: 1914)|publisher=[[Global Biodiversity Information Facility]]|accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref>  Its common names include green citrus aphid
column7: <ref name=\"National Biodiversity Network - 2013 - Aphis (Aphis) spiraecola Patch
column8: 1914 (Green Citrus Aphid)\">{{cite web|url=https://data.nbn.org.uk/Taxa/NHMSYS0020738192|title=Aphis (Aphis) spiraecola Patch
column9: 1914 (Green Citrus Aphid)|date=2013|publisher=[[National Biodiversity Network]]|accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> Spirea aphid
column10: <ref name=\"Michigan State University - 14 May 2014 - MSU IPM Program - Spirea aphid\">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipm.msu.edu/insects/spirea_aphid|title=MSU IPM Program - Spirea aphid|date=14 May 2014|work=MSU IPM Program|publisher=[[Michigan State University]]|accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> and apple aphid.<ref name=\"Atlas of Living Australia - Aphis spiraecola (Patch
column11: 1914) - Apple Aphid\">{{cite web|url=http://bie.ala.org.au/species/Apple+Aphid|title=Aphis spiraecola (Patch
column12: 1914) - Apple Aphid|publisher=[[Atlas of Living Australia]]|accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref> It is a relatively small member of the Aphid species
column13: and is distributed worldwide
column14: most abundant in the United States.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tang|first=Y. Q.|last2=Yokomi|first2=R. '''James P. Conrad''' (born February 12, 1977) is an American retired [[soccer]] player who played as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]]. During his 13-year MLS career, he was four-time [[MLS Best XI]] and the 2005 [[MLS Defender of the Year Award|MLS Defender of the Year]]. He also earned 27 [[cap (sports)|caps]] with the [[United States men's national soccer team]] and went to the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]. After his playing career Conrad has worked in the media industry <ref>{{cite web|last=Laird |first=Sam |url=http://mashable.com/2014/04/19/soccer-youtube-jimmy-conrad-kick-tv/#0nOvi.RJSkqM |title=A Soccer Star's Transition From the Pitch to YouTube |publisher=Mashable |date=2014-04-20 |accessdate=2016-10-24}}</ref> and currently stars on his [[YouTube]] channel [https://www.youtube.com/user/TheJimmyConrad Jimmy Conrad]. He currently serves as the head coach of [[USL League Two]] side [[San Francisco Glens]].

==Career==

===High school and college===
Born in [[Arcadia, California]], Conrad attended [[Temple City High School]] in [[Temple City, California]] and was a four-year letterman in soccer. Conrad played at [[San Diego State University]] in 1994 and 1995, and then transferred to the [[University of California, Los Angeles]]. While playing for UCLA, he was a member of the 1997 [[NCAA Men's Soccer Championship|NCAA Championship]] team.

===Professional===
Undrafted by MLS, Conrad had an unsuccessful trial with the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]].  However, the Galaxy coaching staff recommended he play for one of their affiliated lower division teams.  Consequently, Conrad contacted the now-defunct [[San Diego Flash]] of the [[USL First Division|A-League]] which gave him a contract.  In 1999, [[Brian Quinn (soccer)|Brian Quinn]] became the head coach of the [[San Jose Clash]].  When Quinn began searching for an additional defender and goalkeeper for the Clash, [[Ralf Wilhelms]], head coach of the Flash and a former teammate of Quinn on the [[San Diego Sockers (1974–96)|San Diego Sockers]], recommended Conrad and Flash goalkeeper [[Joe Cannon (soccer)|Joe Cannon]].<ref>[http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/20060118-9999-lz1s18soccr-1.html Often-overlooked Jimmy Conrad, now with national team, has proved doubters wrong]</ref>  The Clash signed Conrad that year.  He played with the club, later re-branded as the Earthquakes, for four seasons, helping them to the [[MLS Cup]] in 2001. In 2000, he also played for [[Lech Poznań]] in Poland.

In 2003, Conrad was traded to the Wizards for a second-round draft pick, which the 'Quakes used to select [[Arturo Álvarez (footballer, born 1985)|Arturo Alvarez]]. Conrad's stock rose while with Kansas City; never a big scorer, he tallied four goals during his first season (he has ten in his MLS career). In 2004, he helped the Wizards to the [[US Open Cup]] and the MLS Cup Final as the leader of the league's stingiest defense and was named to the league's [[MLS Best XI|Best XI]] and was a finalist for [[MLS Defender of the Year Award]]. He won the award a year later.

Despite rumors of a possible European transfer following the Wizards' disappointing 2006 season, Conrad renewed his contract with the Wizards beginning the 2007 season, and new head coach [[Curt Onalfo]] rewarded him the club captaincy.

Conrad was out of contract after the [[2010 MLS season]] and elected to participate in the [[2010 MLS Re-Entry Draft]]. On December 15, 2010 Conrad was selected by [[Chivas USA]] in Stage 2 of the Re-Entry draft.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/wolff-angel-selected-re-entry-stage-2-draft |title=Wolff goes 1st in Stage 2 Re-Entry Draft, Ángel to LA  |work=www.mlssoccer.com |publisher=Major League Soccer |date=15 December 2010 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101219135941/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/wolff-angel-selected-re-entry-stage-2-draft |archivedate=19 December 2010 |quote=Wolff's former Kansas City teammate Jimmy Conrad also went in the early going on Wednesday, taken second overall by Chivas USA. Conrad spent the last eight seasons in Kansas City and was a perennial All-Star during his time there, and could join a Chivas USA team largely in-flux after missing the postseason in 2010.}}</ref> He made his debut, and scored his first goal for his new team on March 19, 2011 in their first game of the 2011 MLS season – ironically against his old club, [[Sporting Kansas City]].<ref>[http://www.mlssoccer.com/matchcenter-recap/bravos-debut-double-sporting-sinks-chivas-usa Bravo's debut double for Sporting sinks Chivas USA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322041022/http://www.mlssoccer.com/matchcenter-recap/bravos-debut-double-sporting-sinks-chivas-usa |date=2011-03-22 }}</ref>

After struggling with injury during the 2011 season, and suffering from side effects of six concussions, Jimmy Conrad announced his retirement from professional soccer on August 18, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ratterree |first=Alicia |url=http://www.thegoatparade.com/2011/8/17/2369285/jimmy-conrad-retires-from-mls |title=Jimmy Conrad Retires from MLS |publisher=The Goat Parade |date=2011-08-17 |accessdate=2012-08-24}}</ref>

===International===
Conrad received his first cap for the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States national team]] on July 7, 2005, in a [[2005 CONCACAF Gold Cup|Gold Cup]] match against [[Cuba national football team|Cuba]]. Less than one year later, Conrad made the U.S. roster for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]. In Germany, Conrad came in as a substitute against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in the team's 1–1 draw with the eventual champions, and played all ninety minutes against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]]. On January 20, 2007, Conrad captained the national team for the second time, where the United States hosted an international [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]]. The U.S. won that match 3–1. On February 7, 2007, in an international friendly with [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]], Conrad was named the [[Man of the Match]]. He scored his first-ever goal for the U.S. in the fifty-second minute of that match. On June 25, 2009, after not having played with the national team in previous qualifying, Conrad was named to the U.S. squad for the upcoming [[CONCACAF Gold Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usmen.american-soccer-news.com/?p=250|title=Article from American Soccer News|publisher=Usmen.american-soccer-news.com|accessdate=2012-08-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224183627/http://usmen.american-soccer-news.com/?p=250|archive-date=2012-02-24|url-status=dead}}</ref>

===Coaching===
In September 2018, Conrad became technical director and head associate coach of the [[San Francisco Glens]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Redd |first=Matt |url=https://www.uslleaguetwo.com/news_article/show/968175 |title=Jimmy Conrad Brings Creative, Professional Experience To San Francisco |publisher=USL League Two |date=2018-11-19 |accessdate=2018-11-25}}</ref> He was named head coach of the Glens ahead of the 2020 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sfglens.com/news_article/show/1083370 |title=JIMMY CONRAD TO SUCCEED JAVIER AYALA-HIL AS 2020 SF GLENS COACH |website=sfglens.com |date=February 4, 2020 |accessdate=February 4, 2020}}</ref>

==='''Honors'''===
'''Kansas City Wzards'''
*[[U.S. Open Cup]]: 2004

'''Individual'''
[[MLS Best XI]] (4): 2004, 2005, 2006, 2008
[[MLS Defender of the Year]]: 2005

column4:
{{Infobox album | name = Murder Love | type = [[Album]] | artist = [[Snow (musician)|Snow]] | cover = Murder_Love.jpg | alt = | released = {{start date|1995|02|21}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = The Mixing Lab ([[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]])
Bayside Sound ([[Queens]])
[[Cherry Beach Sound]] ([[Toronto]])
Soundtrek Studios ([[New York City|New York]]) | genre = {{hlist|[[Pop Music|Pop]]|[[reggae fusion]]}} | length = {{duration|m=53|s=46}} | label = [[East West Records]] | producer = {{hlist|[[MC Shan]]|[[Junior Reid]]|Hurby \Luv Bug\" Azor|Michael Warner|John Ficarrotta}}

column1: | single1     = [[Si Wi Dem Nuh Know We]]
| single2     = [[Anything for You (Snow song)|Anything for You]]

'''''Murder Love''''' is [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[reggae]] musician [[Snow (musician)|Snow]]’s second album. While his preceding album (''[[12 Inches of Snow]]'') featured a wide array of musical genres fusing [[hip-hop]]
column4: ''Murder Love'' was recorded in [[Jamaica]] and primarily featured [[Dancehall reggae|dancehall]] tracks.  A number of songs featured dancehall legends [[Ninjaman]]
column5: [[Half Pint]]
column6: White Mice
column7: and [[Nadine Sutherland]]
column8: and [[Junior Reid]] produced and appeared on the track \"[[Si Wi Dem Nuh Know We]]\". While not producing a hit in the United States
column9: the track \"[[Sexy Girl (Song)|Sexy Girl]]\" reached number one in Japan (becoming the 6th biggest hit of 1995) and the [[Anything for You (Snow song)|\"Anything for You\"]] remix became the top-selling single of 1995 in Jamaica.<ref name=\"See Patricia Meschino 1995\">See Patricia Meschino
column10: ''Reggae Roots'' Vol. 13:3 (1995).</ref><ref name=\"allmusic.com\">For U.S. charting see: {{Allmusic|class=artist|id=snow-p26072/charts-awards|pure_url=yes}}</ref><ref>Jamaican sales and charting data for \"Anything For You\" can be found in Kevin O'Brien Chang and Wayne Chen
column11: ''Reggae Routes: The Story of Jamaican music'' (Philadelphia: Temple University Press
column12: 1998) 211.</ref><ref>For charting in Japan
column13: see: http://www.j-wave.co.jp/original/tokiohot100/cgi-bin/top100.cgi</ref> Ultimately
column14: ''Murder Love'' reached number one the U.S. Reggae charts and \"Si We Dem Nuh Know We\" was nominated for a [[Juno Awards of 1996|Juno]] for best reggae recording. Due to his criminal record
column15: Snow was unable to enter the United States and promote the album.<ref name=\"See Patricia Meschino 1995\"/><ref name=\"allmusic.com\"/>

column3: performing at such venues as the [[University of the West Indies]]
column4: Topline
column5: and the Jaguar Lounge in Halfway Tree. While performing at Sun Splash ’93
column6: he befriended Ninjaman and the two began collaborating. As Snow put it
column7: \"we just clicked
column8: so now we always hang out. Everyday when I'm in [[Jamaica]] I hang with him. When he's doing a track
column9: he'll always invite me to come on it with him.\" In addition to working with Ninjaman
column10: Snow began recording with one of the artists that influenced his interest in reggae
column11: Junior Reid
column12: who went on to produce the track that also featured Snow and Ninjaman
column13: \"Si We Dem Nuh Know We.\"<ref name=\"See Patricia Meschino 1995\"/> Junior Reid also performed as guest vocalist on \"Yesterday.\" Ninjaman also appeared as a guest vocalist on \"Bad Men.\" Nadine Sutherland performed on the first single
column14: \"Anything For You\"
column15: and Half-Pint performs on \"Rivertown\" and joins White Mice on \"Time.\" The album featured several producers
column16: including Junior Reid (\"Si We Dem Nuh Know We\")
column18: \" \"Rivertown
column24: [[MC Shan]] (\"Yesterday\" and \"Sexy Girl\") and Herby Azor ([[Anything for You (Snow song)|\"Anything for You\"]] and \"Things to Say\").<ref>For credits

column2: Snow spent eight months in Jamaica recording the album
column4: including [[M.C. Shan]]
column5: [[Hurby Azor]]
column6: and Michael Warner
column7: flew to Jamaica to contribute to the album. Snow professed: \"The experience of being in Jamaica definitely shaped the album. When I'm working
column8: I don't listen to other music
column9: for fear of stealing something unconsciously. But down there
column10: you can't get away from music
column11: it's all around you.\" He also observed
column12: \"The forward thing in dancehall reggae now is being positive
column13: not singing all the time about gun talk and women. More than the beats
column14: that had an influence in how the songs came out. Because I was going in that direction
column15: it came together naturally.\"<ref>Lenny Stoute
column16: \"Snow melting away from gangsta talk on new disc Rapper says he's seen the folly of his ways
column18: 16 February 1995

column1: The name ''Murder Love'' materialized after Snow visited [[Ireland]] during his European tour in 1994. As he explained in 1995
column2: \"It's about the IRA ([[Irish Republican Army]]).  They're killing people they should be loving. I'm saying to Catholics and Protestants
column3: they should be loving because they're one people. I always write words that are hard to understand. You've got to listen. It could mean something different to you
column4: and if it means something different to you that's good. But that's what it means to me.\" Thus
column5: ''The Mail and Globe'' described the track as the \"sinisterly named title track
column6: which has a deceptively lovely chorus.\" <ref>Elizabeth Renzetti
column7: \"White on Black: The Rap on Rap
column8: \" The Globe and Mail
column9: 11 March 1995

column4: 00.html|title=Murder Love|last=Bernard|first=James|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|date=February 24
column5: 1995|accessdate=June 23

column2: ''Murder Love'' met with mixed reviews. Patricia Meschino of ''Reggae Report'' praised \"Dream\" as one of the albums \"most satisfying cuts.\"  She observed
column3: \"Here Snow reminisces about his days in [[Toronto]]'s Allenbury housing project
column4: where he first became acquainted with Reggae through the friendships formed with the many [[Jamaicans]] who had moved into his area\" and \"goes on to describe imagined evenings spent at [[Kingston
column5: Jamaica|Kingston]]'s Godfather's nightclub and sessions with the Stone Love sound system.\"<ref name=\"See Patricia Meschino 1995\"/> Heidi Seigmund of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote
column6: \"comparisons to rapper [[Vanilla Ice]] were inevitable in '93\" but
column7: \"aside from being white artists working in black-music genres
column8: the similarities end there.\" She went on to observe that \"unlike Ice
column9: Snow really is a skilled performer and an exceptional dancehall talent. That's evident on songs like \"Anything for You
column10: \" a buoyant duet with Nadine Sutherland
column11: \"Things to Say\"—a [[Bob Marley]] tribute sampling [[Bill Withers]]' \"[[Use Me (Bill Withers song)|Use Me]]\"—and \"Rivertown
column12: \" a look at a Jamaican ghetto through the eyes of its young residents.\"<ref>Heidi Sigmund
column13: \"Snow Shows Off Dance Talent on ‘Love
column14: ’\" Review of ''Murder Love''
column15: ''Los Angeles Times''
column16: 15 April 1995

column1: Chuck Eddy of ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' found ''Murder Love'' somewhat indecipherable and a departure from ''12 Inches of Snow''
column2: writing \"slow make out mush replaces the debut’s Algerian-rai/dancehall mix with some lighthearted Marvin Gaye liquid funk
column4: Snow seems to have learned to rap by studying [[Dick Van Dyke]]’s ‘hum-diddle-diddle-did-die-hum-diddl-eye’ chimney sweep scat in [[Mary Poppins (film)|Mary Poppins]]. So I can’t guarantee I got the plots of these poems completely right.\"<ref>Chuck Eddy
column5: Review of ''Murder Love''
column6: ''Spin''
column7: April 1995

*\"Bad Men\" samples \"[[Jungle Boogie]]\" performed by [[Kool & the Gang]]
column4: Robert Mickens
column5: Donald Boyce
column6: Richard Westfield
column7: Dennis Thomas
column8: [[Robert \"Kool\" Bell|Robert Bell]] and George Brown.

column2: samples \"[[Use Me (Bill Withers song)|Use Me]]\" written and performed by [[Bill Withers]].

The schedule consisted of a total of 27 games. Each team played three games against every opponent in no particular order. At least one of the games was at home and one was away. The additional home game for every match-up was randomly assigned prior to the season.

column4:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox rail service | box_width = auto | name = ''Thar Express'' | logo = | logo_width = | image = | image_width = | caption = | type = [[Inter-city rail]] | status = | locale = | predecessor = | first = 2006{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/179498|title=Travelling on the Thar Express|date=20 February 2006|newspaper=Dawn|accessdate=17 November 2018}} | last = | successor = | operator = [[Pakistan Railways]] | formeroperator= | ridership = | start = [[Karachi Cantonment railway station|Karachi Cantonment]] | stops = 3 | end = [[Zero Point railway station|Zero Point]] | distance = {{convert|381|km|mi}} | journeytime = 7 hours, 5 minutes | frequency = Weekly | trainnumber = 405UP (Karachi→Zero Point)
406DN (Zero Point→Karachi){{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1157270|title=Over 200 ticketless passengers travelled to India on Thar Express|first=|last=Bhagwandas|date=16 January 2015|publisher=}} | class = Economy | access = | seating = | sleeping = Not available | autorack = | catering = Not available | observation = | entertainment = | baggage = | otherfacilities = | stock = | gauge = {{RailGauge|1676mm|lk=on}} | el = | speed = | owners = | routenumber = | map = | map_state = }} '''''Thar Express''''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|'''تھر ایکسپریس'''}}}}, [[Sindhi language|Sindhi:]] '''ٿر ايڪسپريس''') is an international [[passenger train]] operated weekly by [[Pakistan Railways]] between [[Karachi]] and [[Khokhrapar]],{{cite web|url=http://www.irfca.org/docs/pak-train-names.html| title=Pakistan Railway Train Names| first=Owais| last=Mughal| date=29 October 2004| accessdate=19 June 2017| publisher=Indian Railways Fan Club| website=irfca.org}} linking with the '''Thar Link Express''' ({{lang-hi|थार लिंक एक्सप्रेस}}) operated weekly by [[Indian Railway]] using its own coaches and locomotives
column5: between [[Munabao]] and [[Jodhpur]].<ref name=IndTr>{{cite web|url=http://m.greaterkashmir.com/news/news/india-to-operate-thar-express-for-6-months/10969.html|title=Greater Kashmir news|publisher=}}</ref> Passengers from Munabao clear customs and are transported to across the border to [[Zero Point railway station|Zero Point station]] where the Thar Express takes passengers to [[Karachi]]
column6: [[Pakistan]].

column1: The Pakistan leg takes approximately 7 hours
column2: 5 minutes to cover a published distance of {{convert|381|km|mi}}

column2: India and Pakistan signed the rail communication agreement
column3: to normalise the relations between two nations after signing the [[Simla Agreement]] (2 July 1972) few months after the end of [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]]
column4: when the bilateral relations had soured after the [[Indian Army]] had succeeded in [[Bangladesh Liberation War|liberating Bangladesh]]. The renewable rail communication agreement was again extended by both nations from 19 January 2016 to 18 January 2019. This agreement forms the basis of running Thar Link Express
column5: as well as the [[Samjhauta Express]]. The [[Delhi–Lahore Bus]] and [[Srinagar-Muzaffarabad Bus]] are based on a separated agreement.

column1: The Thar Express is a continuation of the previous ''[[Sind Mail]]'' which was revived after a period of 41 years on 18 February 2006. The Thar Express travels along the [[Hyderabad–Khokhrapar Branch Line]] which was built in 1892 as the ''Hyderabad–Jodhpur Railway'' and was originally constructed as a {{RailGauge|1676mm}} [[broad gauge]] railway line. In 1901
column2: the section was converted to {{RailGauge|1000mm}} [[metre gauge]] where it joined the second section between Shadipalli and [[Luni Junction railway station|Luni]] and on wards to [[Jodhpur]].<ref name=name>[https://archive.org/stream/BombayBarodaAndCentralIndiaRailwaySystem/Bombay_Baroda_And_Central_India_Railway_System#page/n196/mode/2up  \" Administration Report on the Railways in India – corrected up to 31st March 1918\"; Superintendent of Government  Printing

column4: the entire Hyderabad–Khokhrapar line was re-converted again back to the original 1676 mm broad gauge line. Prior to 1965
column5: the last station was [[Khokhropar railway station]]
column6: about 10 kilometers from the border. When the new service began in 2006
column7: Pakistan Railways constructed a new station
column8: called [[Zero Point railway station]]
column9: a few hundred meter from the border
column10: where immigration and customs checks are carried out now. Opposite this
column11: six kilometers apart
column12: [[Munabao railway station]] is located on the Indian side of the border in [[Barmer district]] of [[Rajasthan]]
column13: where Indian immigration and customs checks are carried out.

column1: The non-stop weekly train is operated by the [[Jodhpur railway division]] of the [[North Western Railway zone]] of Indian Railways. The train is formed with the Indian rolling stock and locomotive for end to end journey in both directions
column2: from Jodhpur to Karachi. The train is formed with one diesel locomotive and 9 standard Indian [[ICF Coaches]] in the following combination
column4: SLR Seating cum luggage rake
column5: S - Seating rake).<ref name=TharTr3>[http://indiarailinfo.com/train/map/train-running-status-thar-link-express-14890/993/2269/2268 Thar Link Express]
column6: Indian Rail Info.</ref>

column1: The train begins its journey with the Indian rolling stock and locomotive from the [[Bhagat Ki Kothi railway station]] in [[Jodhpur]]
column4: where it crosses the border to Pakistan
column5: traveling along a stretch of the [[Hyderabad–Khokhrapar Branch Line]] and [[Karachi–Peshawar Railway Line]]. The trip takes approximately 12 hours and 15 minutes to cover a published distance of {{convert|381|km|mi}}
column6: departing from Bhagat Ki Kothi every Saturday 01:00 [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] and arriving at [[Munabao]] at 07:00 IST. After customs
column7: it crosses the border into Pakistan and arrives at [[Zero Point Railway Station|Zero Point]] at 14:30 PST and reaches Karachi Cantonment at 2:15 PST on Sunday.<ref name=TharTr2>{{cite web|url=http://www.seat61.com/Pakistan.htm |title=Train travel in Pakistan - a beginner's guide |publisher=Seat61.com |date=2006-02-17 |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>

column1: [[File:Karachi Cantt Train Railway Station.jpg|thumb|right|[[Karachi Cantonment Railway Station]]
column2: the destination point of the train
column3: where return journey begins.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.geo.tv/12-4-2010/75294.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-21 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105192658/http://www.geo.tv/12-4-2010/75294.htm |archivedate=5 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>]]

column1: The trip takes approximately 7 hours and 5 minutes to cover a published distance of 381 kilometers (237 mi)
column2: traveling along a stretch of the [[Karachi–Peshawar Railway Line]] and [[Hyderabad–Khokhrapar Branch Line]]. The train departs [[Karachi Cantonment railway station]] every Friday at 23:45 [[Pakistan Standard Time|PST]] and arrives at [[Zero Point railway station]] near [[Khokhrapar]] at 07:00 PST on Saturday. Zero Point serves as the final station on the Pakistani side
column3: whereby passengers clear customs and cross the border into India to arrive at the border town of [[Munabao]]. Passengers then have to buy tickets for the [[Thar Link Express]] which departs to Bhagat Ki Kothi in [[Jodhpur]]. On the return leg
column4: the train departs Zero Point railway station on Saturday at 17:00 PST and arrives at Karachi Cantonment railway station at 01:00 PST on Sunday.

column2: the only other surviving train between India and Pakistan

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox rail service | box_width = auto | name = ''Thar Express'' | logo = | logo_width = | image = | image_width = | caption = | type = [[Inter-city rail]] | status = | locale = | predecessor = | first = 2006{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/179498|title=Travelling on the Thar Express|date=20 February 2006|newspaper=Dawn|accessdate=17 November 2018}} | last = | successor = | operator = [[Pakistan Railways]] | formeroperator= | ridership = | start = [[Karachi Cantonment railway station|Karachi Cantonment]] | stops = 3 | end = [[Zero Point railway station|Zero Point]] | distance = {{convert|381|km|mi}} | journeytime = 7 hours, 5 minutes | frequency = Weekly | trainnumber = 405UP (Karachi→Zero Point)
406DN (Zero Point→Karachi){{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1157270|title=Over 200 ticketless passengers travelled to India on Thar Express|first=|last=Bhagwandas|date=16 January 2015|publisher=}} | class = Economy | access = | seating = | sleeping = Not available | autorack = | catering = Not available | observation = | entertainment = | baggage = | otherfacilities = | stock = | gauge = {{RailGauge|1676mm|lk=on}} | el = | speed = | owners = | routenumber = | map = | map_state = }} '''''Thar Express''''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|'''تھر ایکسپریس'''}}}}, [[Sindhi language|Sindhi:]] '''ٿر ايڪسپريس''') is an international [[passenger train]] operated weekly by [[Pakistan Railways]] between [[Karachi]] and [[Khokhrapar]],{{cite web|url=http://www.irfca.org/docs/pak-train-names.html| title=Pakistan Railway Train Names| first=Owais| last=Mughal| date=29 October 2004| accessdate=19 June 2017| publisher=Indian Railways Fan Club| website=irfca.org}} linking with the '''Thar Link Express''' ({{lang-hi|थार लिंक एक्सप्रेस}}) operated weekly by [[Indian Railway]] using its own coaches and locomotives
column3: between [[Munabao]] and [[Jodhpur]].<ref name=IndTr>{{cite web|url=http://m.greaterkashmir.com/news/news/india-to-operate-thar-express-for-6-months/10969.html|title=Greater Kashmir news|publisher=}}</ref> Passengers from Munabao clear customs and are transported to across the border to [[Zero Point railway station|Zero Point station]] where the [[Thar Express]] takes passengers to [[Karachi]]
column4: [[Pakistan]].

The '''Middle East Broadcasting Networks''' (MBN) is an American Arabic-language non-profit media organization broadcasting news and information across the Middle East and North Africa region.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-image-war/|title=The Image War|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

MBN comprises two television networks, ([[Alhurra]] and Alhurra-Iraq), [[Radio Sawa]], and several digital properties (Alhurra.com, RadioSawa.com, Irfaasawtak.com, MaghrebVoices.com, and Elsaha.com). MBN is financed by the U.S. government through a grant from the [[U.S. Agency for Global Media]] (USAGM), an independent federal agency that serves as a firewall to protect journalists from political influence. Including MBN, there are four other networks under the USAGM umbrella: [[Voice of America]] (VOA), [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]], [[Radio y Televisión Martí|Radio y Television Marti]], and [[Radio Free Asia]].  Former U.S. diplomat, [[Alberto Fernandez (diplomat)|Ambassador Alberto Fernandez]] was appointed as head of MBN in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://providencemag.com/2018/10/robert-nicholson-middle-east-policy-middle-east-broadcasting-networks-mbn-alberto-fernandez/|title=America Talks to the Middle East an Interview with MBN’s Alberto Fernandez|date=2018-10-11|website=Providence|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/the-americas/arabic-tv-station-al-hurra-should-have-rivalled-al-jazeera-but-has-yet-to-find-its-voice-1.617037|title=Arabic TV station Al Hurra should have rivalled Al Jazeera, but has yet to find its voice|website=The National|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/alberto-fernandez-named-head-bbg-middle-east-networks-166491|title=Alberto Fernandez Named Head of BBG Middle East Networks|last=Eggerton|first=John|website=Broadcasting & Cable|language=en-us|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>  On November 4, 2018, MBN relaunched and introduced innovative new programming across all platforms.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thearabweekly.com/relaunched-alhurra-tv-challenge-extremists-conspiracy-theorists|title=Relaunched Alhurra TV to challenge extremists, conspiracy theorists {{!}} AW staff|website=AW|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Reporting-from-Afrin-amid-the-Turkish-offensive-542599|title=Reporting from Afrin amid the Turkish offensive – Middle East – Jerusalem Post|website=www.jpost.com|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

MBN's mission in to provide accurate and objective information on the [[MENA]] region, American policies and Americana, as well as in-depth analysis focusing on topics not found in other [[Arabic media|Arab media]] outlets to encourage transparency and democracy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1658915|title=Live from Virginia, It's Alhurra|website=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref> After airing an investigative report alleging corruption within Iraq's Sunni and Shiite religious establishments, Iraqi authorities suspended the license of MBN's Alhurra television channel for three months.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/f82f7e7426784a4fa008d066c85c2432|title=Iraq suspends US-funded TV station for 3 months over program|date=2019-09-02|website=AP NEWS|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2019/sep/2/alhurra-us-funded-tv-iraq-suspended-after-alleging/|title=Iraq suspends Alhurra, a U.S.-funded TV station, after alleging corruption in report|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first=The Washington Times|website=The Washington Times|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

== History and funding ==
The purpose of launching MBN and its networks was to counter perceived anti-American bias promoted by the leading Arab and international television networks and the effect these channels were having on Arab public opinion regarding the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uscpublicdiplomacy.org/blog/pushing-back-russian-disinformation-arab-countries|title=Pushing Back on Russian Disinformation in Arab Countries {{!}} USC Center on Public Diplomacy|website=www.uscpublicdiplomacy.org|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref> MBN and its networks are intended to serve as an alternative to these channels by presenting the news in a more balanced and objective manner in an effort to improve the image of the United States in the Arab world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-image-war/|title=The Image War|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/theprotojournalist/2014/08/06/337781755/hearts-minds-tweets-battling-terrorism-online|title=Hearts, Minds, Tweets: Battling Terrorism Online|website=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

[[Norman Pattiz]], founder and chairman of mass-media company [[Westwood One (1976–2011)|Westwood One]], was the driving force behind the launch of Radio Sawa in 2002, a USAGM-administered Arabic-language radio network which broadcasts a mix of music and news.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720223228/http://people.forbes.com/profile/norman-j-pattiz/86314|title=Norman J. Pattiz Profile – Forbes.com|date=2011-07-20|website=web.archive.org|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>  Pattiz served as a board member of the then BBG, currently the U.S. Agency for Global Media (USAGM), the U.S. independent federal agency that oversees all foreign non-military radio and TV broadcasts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728174441/http://www.access.gpo.gov/congress/senate/pdf/108hrg/95841.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=2010-07-28|website=web.archive.org|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

The idea to launch Alhurra in 2004 stemmed from the success of Radio Sawa in reaching young audiences in the Middle East.  Pattiz believed that Arab audiences’ views of the United States were being negatively influenced by existing Arab news networks’ focus on coverage of the wars in Iraq, Afghanistan, and the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. He envisioned that by presenting a wider range of perspectives on these conflicts and other U.S. policies, as well as coverage of a broader variety of regional and global issues of interest to Arab audiences, a U.S.-funded satellite TV channel could help improve America's image in the region.  In pursuit of Pattiz's vision, the Bush administration requested appropriations for the channel from Congress, and obtained $62 million in funding for the channel's first year of operation (including start-up costs). In the fall of 2003, construction began to renovate an existing TV station in Springfield, VA into a modern broadcast facility for the new channel. Construction was completed less than six months later, and Alhurra's first broadcast aired February 14, 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-image-war/|title=The Image War|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

== Programming ==
In the restructuring and relaunch of Alhurra TV, the station has increased its newscasts from 4 to 12 hours each day delivered by an all-new lineup of news anchors and news programs, and incorporated live broadcasts from new studios near [[Washington, D.C.|Washington D.C.]] and [[Dubai]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thearabweekly.com/relaunched-alhurra-tv-challenge-extremists-conspiracy-theorists|title=Relaunched Alhurra TV to challenge extremists, conspiracy theorists {{!}} AW staff|website=AW|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.arabnews.com/node/1399901/media|title=US-backed Alhurra TV relaunches amid new Iran sanctions|date=2018-11-06|website=Arab News|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref> Alhurra also has introduced news segments on issues related to North Africa and taking a deeper dive into news stories from the U.S.  New programs include “Debatable,” a weekly show presented by Ibrahim Issa, that discusses in depth critical analysis of political Islam; “Word of Truth,” a weekly show presented by Joumana Haddad, that provides a platform for silenced intellectual voices to share ideas marginalized in Arab countries; “Free Islam,” presented by Islam al-Buhairi, exploring enlightenment values and adapting them and incorporating them into “free, moderate Islam” as part of daily life;  “Sam and Ammar,” a weekly show hosted by two liberal intellectuals who share their unfiltered and cutting edge views on current affairs and spotlight Washington's political and economic decisions that impact the MENA region; “Investigative Reports,” a weekly show that aims to conduct deep investigative reports from an all-new investigative news unit; “The Talk is Syrian,” a weekly show that examines the ongoing conflict in Syria; “Decision’s Capital,” a weekly show analyzing US foreign policy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usagm.gov/2018/11/03/a-new-and-revitalized-alhurra-tv-launches-across-the-middle-east/|title=A new and revitalized Alhurra TV launches across the Middle East|website=USAGM|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

The '''Middle East Broadcasting Networks''' (MBN) is an American Arabic-language non-profit media organization broadcasting news and information across the Middle East and North Africa region.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-image-war/|title=The Image War|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

MBN comprises two television networks, ([[Alhurra]] and Alhurra-Iraq), [[Radio Sawa]], and several digital properties (Alhurra.com, RadioSawa.com, Irfaasawtak.com, MaghrebVoices.com, and Elsaha.com). MBN is financed by the U.S. government through a grant from the [[U.S. Agency for Global Media]] (USAGM), an independent federal agency that serves as a firewall to protect journalists from political influence. Including MBN, there are four other networks under the USAGM umbrella: [[Voice of America]] (VOA), [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]], [[Radio y Televisión Martí|Radio y Television Marti]], and [[Radio Free Asia]].  Former U.S. diplomat, [[Alberto Fernandez (diplomat)|Ambassador Alberto Fernandez]] was appointed as head of MBN in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://providencemag.com/2018/10/robert-nicholson-middle-east-policy-middle-east-broadcasting-networks-mbn-alberto-fernandez/|title=America Talks to the Middle East an Interview with MBN’s Alberto Fernandez|date=2018-10-11|website=Providence|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/the-americas/arabic-tv-station-al-hurra-should-have-rivalled-al-jazeera-but-has-yet-to-find-its-voice-1.617037|title=Arabic TV station Al Hurra should have rivalled Al Jazeera, but has yet to find its voice|website=The National|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/alberto-fernandez-named-head-bbg-middle-east-networks-166491|title=Alberto Fernandez Named Head of BBG Middle East Networks|last=Eggerton|first=John|website=Broadcasting & Cable|language=en-us|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>  On November 4, 2018, MBN relaunched and introduced innovative new programming across all platforms.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thearabweekly.com/relaunched-alhurra-tv-challenge-extremists-conspiracy-theorists|title=Relaunched Alhurra TV to challenge extremists, conspiracy theorists {{!}} AW staff|website=AW|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Reporting-from-Afrin-amid-the-Turkish-offensive-542599|title=Reporting from Afrin amid the Turkish offensive – Middle East – Jerusalem Post|website=www.jpost.com|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

MBN's mission in to provide accurate and objective information on the [[MENA]] region, American policies and Americana, as well as in-depth analysis focusing on topics not found in other [[Arabic media|Arab media]] outlets to encourage transparency and democracy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1658915|title=Live from Virginia, It's Alhurra|website=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref> After airing an investigative report alleging corruption within Iraq's Sunni and Shiite religious establishments, Iraqi authorities suspended the license of MBN's Alhurra television channel for three months.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/f82f7e7426784a4fa008d066c85c2432|title=Iraq suspends US-funded TV station for 3 months over program|date=2019-09-02|website=AP NEWS|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2019/sep/2/alhurra-us-funded-tv-iraq-suspended-after-alleging/|title=Iraq suspends Alhurra, a U.S.-funded TV station, after alleging corruption in report|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first=The Washington Times|website=The Washington Times|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

== History and funding ==
The purpose of launching MBN and its networks was to counter perceived anti-American bias promoted by the leading Arab and international television networks and the effect these channels were having on Arab public opinion regarding the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uscpublicdiplomacy.org/blog/pushing-back-russian-disinformation-arab-countries|title=Pushing Back on Russian Disinformation in Arab Countries {{!}} USC Center on Public Diplomacy|website=www.uscpublicdiplomacy.org|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref> MBN and its networks are intended to serve as an alternative to these channels by presenting the news in a more balanced and objective manner in an effort to improve the image of the United States in the Arab world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-image-war/|title=The Image War|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/theprotojournalist/2014/08/06/337781755/hearts-minds-tweets-battling-terrorism-online|title=Hearts, Minds, Tweets: Battling Terrorism Online|website=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

[[Norman Pattiz]], founder and chairman of mass-media company [[Westwood One (1976–2011)|Westwood One]], was the driving force behind the launch of Radio Sawa in 2002, a USAGM-administered Arabic-language radio network which broadcasts a mix of music and news.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720223228/http://people.forbes.com/profile/norman-j-pattiz/86314|title=Norman J. Pattiz Profile – Forbes.com|date=2011-07-20|website=web.archive.org|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>  Pattiz served as a board member of the then BBG, currently the U.S. Agency for Global Media (USAGM), the U.S. independent federal agency that oversees all foreign non-military radio and TV broadcasts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728174441/http://www.access.gpo.gov/congress/senate/pdf/108hrg/95841.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=2010-07-28|website=web.archive.org|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

The idea to launch Alhurra in 2004 stemmed from the success of Radio Sawa in reaching young audiences in the Middle East.  Pattiz believed that Arab audiences’ views of the United States were being negatively influenced by existing Arab news networks’ focus on coverage of the wars in Iraq, Afghanistan, and the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. He envisioned that by presenting a wider range of perspectives on these conflicts and other U.S. policies, as well as coverage of a broader variety of regional and global issues of interest to Arab audiences, a U.S.-funded satellite TV channel could help improve America's image in the region.  In pursuit of Pattiz's vision, the Bush administration requested appropriations for the channel from Congress, and obtained $62 million in funding for the channel's first year of operation (including start-up costs). In the fall of 2003, construction began to renovate an existing TV station in Springfield, VA into a modern broadcast facility for the new channel. Construction was completed less than six months later, and Alhurra's first broadcast aired February 14, 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-image-war/|title=The Image War|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en|access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>

“Investigative Reports,” a weekly show that aims to conduct deep investigative reports from an all-new investigative news unit; “The Talk is Syrian,” a weekly show that examines the ongoing conflict in Syria; column3: is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese

column5: (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish
column4: Ornate Butterfly
column5: Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish|Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish|Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler
column6: Jennifer L.
column7: and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”
column8: but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish
column9: it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon
column10: which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish|Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these
column11: they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout
column2: and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\">Adam
column3: T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour''

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon|lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\" />. On the other hand
column4: and live in the arms of branching corals for protection <ref name=\":0\" />. Once juveniles reach breeding age
column5: they form pairs <ref name=\":0\" />. It is uncommon to find adult ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'''  without a mate. Pairs also establish a \"home range\" where you will likely always find them <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are monogamous and pair-forming coral reef fish. Many ornate butterflyfish mate for life. Spawning activity occurs at different times depending on each biome. Tropical spawning peaks in winter and early spring
column2: while temperate spawning occurs in midsummer <ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web|url=https://animaldiversity.org/accounts/Chaetodontidae/|title=Chaetodontidae (Butterflyfishes)|last=Weinheimer|first=Monica|last2=Jonna|first2=R. Jamil|website=Animal Diversity Web|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>. Spawning occurs at dusk and eggs are released and fertilized in the water column <ref name=\":7\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics|tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]]
column4: North to Southern [[Japan]]
column5: South to Lord Howe
column6: and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández
column7: Sebastián
column8: et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut|Hsu
column9: Kui-Ching; Chen
column10: Jeng-Ping & Shao
column11: Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine
column12: inshore
column13: tropical (30°N - 30°S
column14: 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers

column16: Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile
column2: benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms
column3: unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett
column4: M. S.
column5: Wilson
column6: S. K.
column7: & Baird
column8: A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology''
column10: 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing
column11: pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however
column12: by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish
column2: specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish
column4: following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al.
column5: revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growth<ref name=\":6\">Brooker
column2: R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6'''
column3: 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).</ref>. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development<ref name=\":6\" />. Coral reef communities provide shelter
column4: and food resources for Butterflyfish<ref name=\":6\" />. However
column5: the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish
column6: as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

column1: ''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species
column2: which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske
column4: August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish|Chaetodon austriacus]]''
column5: ''[[Eastern triangle butterflyfish|C. baronessa]]''
column6: [[Bluelashed butterflyfish|''C. bennetti''
column7: ]] ''[[Chaetodon larvatus|C. larvatus]]''
column8: ''[[Oval butterflyfish|C. lunulatus]]''
column9: [[Scrawled butterflyfish|''C. meyeri''
column10: ]] ''[[Eightband butterflyfish|C. octofasiatus]]''
column11: ''[[Chaetodon rainfordi|C. rainfordi]]
column12: '' and ''[[Melon butterflyfish|C. trifasicatus]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thesprucepets.com/feeding-profile-butterflyfish-family-chaetodontidae-2920779|title=What to Feed Your Butterflyfish|website=The Spruce Pets|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores
column13: which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)|coral polyps]]
column14: tentacles of [[Sabellidae|feather dusters]] and [[Spirobranchus giganteus|Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore
column15: butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral
column16: and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake
column18: turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are one of the most popular tropical fishes with divers and aquarists <ref name=\":7\" />. However
column2: ornate butterflyfish are nearly impossible to successfully keep in captivity because they are obligate corallivores <ref name=\":7\" />.
