column3: is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese
column4: R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2019. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org
column5: (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish
column4: Ornate Butterfly
column5: Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish|Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish|Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler
column6: Jennifer L.
column7: and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”
column8: but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish
column9: it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon
column10: which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish|Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these
column11: they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout
column2: and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\">Adam
column3: T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour''

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon|lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\" />. On the other hand
column4: and live in the arms of branching corals for protection <ref name=\":0\" />. Once juveniles reach breeding age
column5: they form pairs <ref name=\":0\" />. It is uncommon to find adult ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'''  without a mate. Pairs also establish a \"home range\" where you will likely always find them <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' are monogamous and pair-forming coral reef fish. Many ornate butterflyfish mate for life. Spawning activity occurs at different times depending on each biome. Tropical spawning peaks in winter and early spring
column2: while temperate spawning occurs in midsummer <ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web|url=https://animaldiversity.org/accounts/Chaetodontidae/|title=Chaetodontidae (Butterflyfishes)|last=Weinheimer|first=Monica|last2=Jonna|first2=R. Jamil|website=Animal Diversity Web|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>. Spawning occurs at dusk and eggs are released and fertilized in the water column <ref name=\":7\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics|tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]]
column4: North to Southern [[Japan]]
column5: South to Lord Howe
column6: and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández
column7: Sebastián
column8: et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut|Hsu
column9: Kui-Ching; Chen
column10: Jeng-Ping & Shao
column11: Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine
column12: inshore
column13: tropical (30°N - 30°S
column14: 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers
column15: R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada
column16: Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile
column2: benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms
column3: unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett
column4: M. S.
column5: Wilson
column6: S. K.
column7: & Baird
column8: A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology''
column10: 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing
column11: pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however
column12: by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish
column2: specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish
column4: following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al.
column5: revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

column1: Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growth<ref name=\":6\">Brooker
column2: R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6'''
column3: 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).</ref>. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development<ref name=\":6\" />. Coral reef communities provide shelter
column4: and food resources for Butterflyfish<ref name=\":6\" />. However
column5: the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish
column6: as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

column1: ''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species
column2: which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske
column4: August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish|Chaetodon austriacus]]''
column5: ''[[Eastern triangle butterflyfish|C. baronessa]]''
column6: [[Bluelashed butterflyfish|''C. bennetti''
column7: ]] ''[[Chaetodon larvatus|C. larvatus]]''
column8: ''[[Oval butterflyfish|C. lunulatus]]''
column9: [[Scrawled butterflyfish|''C. meyeri''
column10: ]] ''[[Eightband butterflyfish|C. octofasiatus]]''
column11: ''[[Chaetodon rainfordi|C. rainfordi]]
column12: '' and ''[[Melon butterflyfish|C. trifasicatus]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thesprucepets.com/feeding-profile-butterflyfish-family-chaetodontidae-2920779|title=What to Feed Your Butterflyfish|website=The Spruce Pets|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores
column13: which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)|coral polyps]]
column14: tentacles of [[Sabellidae|feather dusters]] and [[Spirobranchus giganteus|Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore
column15: butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral
column16: and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake
column18: turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

'''Monitor Latino''' (stylised '''monitorLATINO''') is a singles chart founded in 2003 which ranks songs on chart based on [[airplay]] across radio stations in [[Latin America|Latin American]] countries and Hispanic radio stations in the United States using the Radio Tracking Data, LLC in real time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://monitorlatino.com/monitoreo-de-comerciales/|title=Monitor Latino - Company|publisher=Monitor Latino|accessdate=2012-05-30}}</ref><ref name=formats>{{cite web|url=http://www.monitorlatino.com.mx/formats.html|title=Monitor Latino - Formats|language=Spanish|publisher=Monitor Latino|accessdate=2012-05-30|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120801020731/http://www.monitorlatino.com.mx/formats.html|archivedate=2012-08-01}}</ref>

Monitor Latino started monitoring radio stations in Mexico and the United States in 2003. The company later expanded into other Latin American markets, and currently it monitors radio stations and issues music charts for 18 countries.

In January 2012, Monitor Latino began surveying radio stations in the [[Dominican Republic]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Venezuela]], and [[Guatemala]], publishing singles chart which were only accessible to subscribers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radionotas.com/Details.aspx?aid=6149|title=Llega a República Dominicana|language=Spanish|date=2012-01-03|work=RadioNotas|publisher=MonitorLatino|accessdate=2012-05-30}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Since 2016, their complete charts are accessible to the general public, and an archive for their weekly charts after July 2014 is available on [http://monitorlatino.com/top-canciones-de-momento-mexico/general/ their website].

Monitor Latino hosts an annual award show which is held in Los Angeles, California.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/playback/2009/09/Faces_Places/ascap_latino_convention.aspx|title=Ascap Latino Sponsors Monitor Latino Convention|date=2009-08-01|accessdate=2012-05-30|publisher=[[ASCAP]]}}</ref> The company has its offices in Los Angeles and in [[Guadalajara, Mexico]].

The '''Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar''' ({{lang-pt|Igreja Matriz de Nossa Senhora do Pilar}}) is an 18th-century [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] church located in [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]], [[Bahia]], [[Brazil]]. It includes a cemetery, constructed in the [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] parallel to the nave of the church. The interior of the church has an extensive set of azulejo tiles in the [[rococo]] style. The historian [[Carlos Ott]] dated them to the late 18th century, and stated that they appear to be the work of the Juncal workshop in Portugal. The stonework of the church is in lioz stone, imported from Lisbon at great expense.<ref name=\hpip\"/><ref name=\"ipac-ba\"/><ref name=\"tarde2011\"/><ref name=\"t\"/>

column1: The church closed in 1994 after heavy rains caused the collapse of a wall of the church; additionally
column2: the [[cemetery]] was used by residents for waste disposal. A restoration project began in 2011
column4: 500 tons of garbage from the cemetery. The Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar reopened in 2015.<ref name=\"hpip\"/><ref name=\"ipac-ba\"/><ref name=\"tarde2011\"/>

column1: [[Image:Igreja de Nossa Senhora do Pilar Nave 2018-0227.jpg|thumb|left|250px|View of nave and chancel.]]
The Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar is located in the Comércio district
column2: in the historic lower city (''cidade baixa'') of Salvador. It was constructed at the base of a large slope below the Carmo district of the higher city. Its location at the base of the slope
column4: has continually put the church at risk of damage caused by landslides.<ref name=\"co1\"/><ref name=\"t\"/>

column1: The Brotherhood of Our Lady of Pilar (''Irmandade do Pilar'') was established in Salvador in 1718. Construction of its church began in 1756 on an undeveloped slope of land beyond the lower city
column3: or Salvador. The cemetery was completed in 1799 on a higher level of terrain than the church building in the Neoclassical style. The church
column4: its internal patio with a fountain
column5: and cemetery at a higher level formed an architectural complex unique to the city of Salvador.<ref name=\"ipac\"/>

column1: Salvador was geographically divided into ten parishes
column4: uniting the functions of the state and church. The Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar became the focal point of the  ''freguesia'' of Santíssimo Sacramento do Pilar; residents were baptized
column5: married
column6: elected local officials
column7: and were buried at the church. Pilar
column8: as one of the commercial areas of the lower city
column9: was home to both wealthy Portuguese merchants and enslaved and freed Afro-Brazilians; the latter worked in domestic labor
column10: as fisherman
column11: and as street vendors.<ref name=\"w\"/>

column1: A fire occurred in December of 1829 that damaged the dressing room (''camirim'') of the chancel and a tribune of the church. It also damaged many sculptures of saints
column2: including the Lord of the Good Way (''Senhor do Bom Caminho'') and the statue of Our Lady of Pilar
column3: the patron saint of the church. The fire also damage or completely melted sacred treasures of the church
column4: including lamps
column5: silver candlesticks
column6: and the tabernacle. These were the work of [[Joaquim Alberto da Conceição e Matos]]. A landslide off the slope occurred on July 9

column8: and was carried away in the landslide killing Father João Nepomuceno Moreira de Pinho
column9: resident of the consistory.

The façade of Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar
column4: and windows
column5: are in ''lioz'' limestone imported from Lisbon. The monument pediment in the Rococo style was added later. The church interior consists of a [[nave]]
column6: altar

column8: [[tribunes]] that open to the inner courtyard
column9: a former sacristy
column10: and other smaller rooms. The painting on the ceiling of the nave is the work of [[José Teófilo de Jesus]]
column11: completed in 1837. The master woodcarver [[Joaquim Francisco de Matos]] completed ''talha'' work on four altars of the nave

column15: and carvings of the baptismal font. The works were contracted in 1838 and completed in the following year; they were ultimately gilded in 1848.<ref name=\"ba\"/><ref name=\"ipac-ba\"/>

column1: The church is home to numerous works of art
column4: and metalwork. The statue of the Lord of the Good Way (''Senhor do Bom Caminho'') is the work of Manuel Inácio da Costa.<ref name=\"t\"/>

column1: The sacristy of the Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar is richly furnished and decorated. A large sacristy cabinet spans the length of the north wall of the room. Six richly painted panels are above the cabinet; they are the work of [[José Joaquim da Rocha]] (1737-1807) and completed in 1796. An ornate stone [[lavabo]] is on the south wall. The sacristy has [[azulejo]] tiles similar to those of the nave and halls.<ref name=\"ipac-ba\"/><ref name=\"peq\"/>
A fountain dedicated to Saint Lucia is located in the interior churchyard at the base of the slope. The fountain is believed to have healing powers
column2: especially for ocular problems. An annual festival dedicated to [[Saint Lucia]] takes place in September
column3: and includes a Mass followed by a procession of the image of Saint Lucia throughout the Comercio district.<ref name=\"ipac-ba\"/><ref name=\"tarde2011\"/>

column1: The Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar was the first Catholic church in Salvador to build an annexed cemetery. The large [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] structure
column2: designed by José de Anchieta Mesquita
column3: was constructed in 1799. An exterior cemetery was an innovation of the period; burials within the church proper caused both sanitary problems and the spread of infectious diseases to parishioners. Other churches in Salvador followed the practice of the construction of an external cemetery in the 19th century.<ref name=\"t\"/><ref name=\"tarde2011\"/>

column1: Residents on the slope between the church and the upper Carmo district used the [[cemetery]] for waste disposal as early as the 19th century. The quantity of garbage caused the collapse of interior walls of the cemetery and cut off access to graves by the 20th century. The restoration project of 2011 saw the removal of 2
column2: 500 tons of garbage from the cemetery and restored access to the tombs and interior altar.<ref name=\"ipac-ba\"/><ref name=\"tarde2011\"/>

column1: The Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar was listed as a historic structure by the [[National Institute of Historic and Artistic Heritage]] in 1938. The church is part of the [[Historic Center (Salvador)|Historic Center of Salvador]] [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]].<ref name=\"ipac\"/>
The Parish Church of Our Lady of Pilar is open to the public and may be visited.

column4:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox album | name = Through the Past, Darkly
(Big Hits Vol. 2) | type = greatest | artist = [[The Rolling Stones]] | cover = Pastdarkly.png | alt = | released = 12 September 1969 | recorded = 8 August 1963 – June 1969 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[psychedelic music|psychedelic]] | length = 42:30 | language = [[English language|English]] | label = [[London Records|London]] (US), [[Decca Records|Decca]] (UK) | producer = [[Andrew Loog Oldham]], The Rolling Stones, [[Jimmy Miller (musician)|Jimmy Miller]] | prev_title = [[Beggars Banquet]] | prev_year = 1968 | next_title = [[Let It Bleed]] | next_year = 1969 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[The Rolling Stones]] compilations | title = Through the Past, Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2) | type = compilation | year = 1966 | prev_title = [[Big Hits (High Tide and Green Grass)]] | prev_year = 1966 | next_title = [[Stone Age (The Rolling Stones album)|Stone Age]] | next_year = 1971 }} }} {{italic title|all=yes|noerror}} '''''Through the Past, Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2)''''' is the second compilation album by the English rock band [[the Rolling Stones]], released in September 1969 by [[Decca Records]] in the UK and [[London Records]]/[[ABKCO Records]] in the US. == Background == According to Bruce Eder of [[AllMusic]], the album resulted from \three coinciding events – the need to acknowledge the death of band co-founder [[Brian Jones]] (whose epitaph graces the inside cover) in July of 1969; the need to get '[[Honky Tonk Women]]
column5: ' then a huge hit single
column6: onto an LP; and to fill the ten-month gap since the release of ''[[Beggars Banquet]]'' and get an album with built-in appeal into stores ahead of the Stones' first American tour in three years.\"<ref name=\"AM\">{{cite web|last=Eder|first=Bruce|date=n.d.|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/through-the-past-darkly-big-hits-vol-2-mw0000191644|title=Through the Past
column7: Darkly: Big Hits
column8: Vol. 2|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>

column1: Because the Stones' [[Big Hits (High Tide and Green Grass)|first ''Big Hits'' compilation]] had been released in separate formats
column2: with the ''[[Aftermath (The Rolling Stones album)|Aftermath]]''-era material appearing only on its UK edition
column3: the American edition of ''Big Hits Vol. 2'' included hit singles from the ''Aftermath'' period.

column1: The British track listing included the more obscure \"[[You Better Move On (song)|You Better Move On]]\"
column2: from The Rolling Stones' [[The Rolling Stones (EP)|self-titled]] 1964 debut [[Extended play|EP]] and \"[[Sittin' on a Fence]]\"
column3: an ''Aftermath'' outtake originally released in 1967 on the US-compiled ''[[Flowers (The Rolling Stones album)|Flowers]]'' album. In addition to those songs
column4: many tracks
column5: notably single-only releases
column6: were collected for the first time on a UK Rolling Stones album: \"[[Let's Spend the Night Together]]\"
column7: \"[[Ruby Tuesday (song)|Ruby Tuesday]]\"
column8: \"[[We Love You]]\"
column9: \"[[Dandelion (song)|Dandelion]]\"
column10: and \"[[Honky Tonk Women]]\".

column1: The name of the album is a play on a line from the [[Authorized King James Version|KJV]] translation of [[First Epistle to the Corinthians|1 Corinthians]] 13: \"For now we see [[through a glass
column4: but then face to face...\"
column5: but it is more likely the Stones intended a homage to [[Ingmar Bergman]] and his 1961 film ''[[Through a Glass Darkly (film)|Through a Glass Darkly]]''.

column1: The LP was packaged in in a six-sided die-cut [[gatefold LP|gatefold sleeve]]
column2: featuring an epitaph for Jones: \"With this you see
column3: remember me and bear me in your mind. Let all the world say what they may
column4: speak of me as you find.\"<ref>{{cite book|title=Old Gods Almost Dead: The 40-Year Odyssey of the Rolling Stones|last=Davis|first=Stephen|year=2001|publisher=Crown|isbn=0767909569|page=316}}</ref>

column2: <ref name=\"Paytress\">{{cite book|last=Paytress|first=Mark|title=Rolling Stones: Off The Record|year=2009|publisher=[[Omnibus Press]]|isbn=0857121138|chapter=Good Times
column3: Bad Times}}</ref> both versions of ''Through the Past
column4: Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2)'' proved to be popular releases
column5: reaching #2 in the UK and US with enduring sales.

column1: In August 2002 the US edition of ''Through the Past
column2: Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2)'' was reissued in a new remastered CD and [[Super Audio CD|SACD]] [[digipak]] by [[ABKCO Records]].

column1: The British version was again made available to the public as part of a limited edition vinyl box set
column3: in November 2010. It was also re-released digitally at the same time.

column1: It was released in 2011 by [[Universal Music Enterprises]] in a Japanese only SHM-[[Super Audio CD|SACD]] version. For Record Store Day 2019 ABKCO Records released the record on orange vinyl
column2: with a gatefold cover in the octagonal-shape of the original issue.

column12: ' 'Child of the Moon
column13: ' and 'You Can't Always Get What You Want
column14: ' which exists in a nine-minute version) remain uncollected. And whose fault is that?\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Christgau|first=Robert|authorlink=Robert Christgau|date=18 September 1969|url=https://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/cg/cg4.php|title=Consumer Guide (4)|newspaper=[[The Village Voice]]|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> More receptive was [[Rob Sheffield]]

column2:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox album | name = Through the Past, Darkly
(Big Hits Vol. 2) | type = greatest | artist = [[The Rolling Stones]] | cover = Pastdarkly.png | alt = | released = 12 September 1969 | recorded = 8 August 1963 – June 1969 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[psychedelic music|psychedelic]] | length = 42:30 | language = [[English language|English]] | label = [[London Records|London]] (US), [[Decca Records|Decca]] (UK) | producer = [[Andrew Loog Oldham]], The Rolling Stones, [[Jimmy Miller (musician)|Jimmy Miller]] | prev_title = [[Beggars Banquet]] | prev_year = 1968 | next_title = [Let It Bleed]] | next_year = 1969 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[The Rolling Stones]] compilations | title = Through the Past, Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2) | type = compilation | year = 1966 | prev_title = [[Big Hits (High Tide and Green Grass)]] | prev_year = 1966 | next_title = [[Stone Age (The Rolling Stones album)|Stone Age]] | next_year = 1971 }} }} {{italic title|all=yes|noerror}} '''''Through the Past, Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2)''''' is the second compilation album by the English rock band [[the Rolling Stones]], released in September 1969 by [[Decca Records]] in the UK and [[London Records]]/[[ABKCO Records]] in the US. == Background == According to Bruce Eder of [[AllMusic]], the album resulted from \three coinciding events – the need to acknowledge the death of band co-founder [[Brian Jones]] (whose epitaph graces the inside cover) in July of 1969; the need to get '[[Honky Tonk Women]]
column4: onto an LP; and to fill the ten-month gap since the release of ''[[Beggars Banquet]]'' and get an album with built-in appeal into stores ahead of the Stones' first American tour in three years.\"<ref name=\"AM\">{{cite web|last=Eder|first=Bruce|date=n.d.|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/through-the-past-darkly-big-hits-vol-2-mw0000191644|title=Through the Past
column5: Darkly: Big Hits
column6: Vol. 2|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>

column1: Because the Stones' [[Big Hits (High Tide and Green Grass)|first ''Big Hits'' compilation]] had been released in separate formats
column2: with the ''[[Aftermath (The Rolling Stones album)|Aftermath]]''-era material appearing only on its UK edition
column3: the American edition of ''Big Hits Vol. 2'' included hit singles from the ''Aftermath'' period.

column1: The British track listing included the more obscure \"[[You Better Move On (song)|You Better Move On]]\"
column2: from The Rolling Stones' [[The Rolling Stones (EP)|self-titled]] 1964 debut [[Extended play|EP]] and \"[[Sittin' on a Fence]]\"
column3: an ''Aftermath'' outtake originally released in 1967 on the US-compiled ''[[Flowers (The Rolling Stones album)|Flowers]]'' album. In addition to those songs
column4: many tracks
column5: notably single-only releases
column6: were collected for the first time on a UK Rolling Stones album: \"[[Let's Spend the Night Together]]\"
column7: \"[[Ruby Tuesday (song)|Ruby Tuesday]]\"
column8: \"[[We Love You]]\"
column9: \"[[Dandelion (song)|Dandelion]]\"
column10: and \"[[Honky Tonk Women]]\".

column1: The name of the album is a play on a line from the [[Authorized King James Version|KJV]] translation of [[First Epistle to the Corinthians|1 Corinthians]] 13: \"For now we see [[through a glass
column4: but then face to face...\"
column5: but it is more likely the Stones intended a homage to [[Ingmar Bergman]] and his 1961 film ''[[Through a Glass Darkly (film)|Through a Glass Darkly]]''.

column1: The LP was packaged in in a six-sided die-cut [[gatefold LP|gatefold sleeve]]
column2: featuring an epitaph for Jones: \"With this you see
column3: remember me and bear me in your mind. Let all the world say what they may
column4: speak of me as you find.\"<ref>{{cite book|title=Old Gods Almost Dead: The 40-Year Odyssey of the Rolling Stones|last=Davis|first=Stephen|year=2001|publisher=Crown|isbn=0767909569|page=316}}</ref>

column2: <ref name=\"Paytress\">{{cite book|last=Paytress|first=Mark|title=Rolling Stones: Off The Record|year=2009|publisher=[[Omnibus Press]]|isbn=0857121138|chapter=Good Times
column3: Bad Times}}</ref> both versions of ''Through the Past
column4: Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2)'' proved to be popular releases
column5: reaching #2 in the UK and US with enduring sales.

column1: In August 2002 the US edition of ''Through the Past
column2: Darkly (Big Hits Vol. 2)'' was reissued in a new remastered CD and [[Super Audio CD|SACD]] [[digipak]] by [[ABKCO Records]].

column1: The British version was again made available to the public as part of a limited edition vinyl box set
column3: in November 2010. It was also re-released digitally at the same time.

column1: It was released in 2011 by [[Universal Music Enterprises]] in a Japanese only SHM-[[Super Audio CD|SACD]] version. For Record Store Day 2019 ABKCO Records released the record on orange vinyl
column2: with a gatefold cover in the octagonal-shape of the original issue.
